PLANT A TREE IN THE AVENUE OF THE RIGHTEOUS. IT GROWS THE

OSKAR SCHINDLER FAILED AT SEVERAL BUSINESSES, AND MARRIAG

AFTER THE WAR IN 1958, HE WAS DECLARED A RIGHTEOUS PERSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The song plays from a radio on a rust-stained sink. The light in the room is dismal, the furniture cheap. The curtains are faded, the wallpaper peeling... but the clot laid out across the single bed are beautiful. The hands of a man button the shirt, belt the slacks. He  slips into the double-breasted jacket, knots the silk tie folds a handkerchief and tucks it into the jacket pocket, all with great deliberation. A bureau. Some currency, cigarettes, liquor, passport. An an elaborate gold-on-black enamel Hakenkreuz (or swastika which the gentleman pins to the lapel of his elegant dinn jacket. He steps back to consider his reflection in the mirror. H likes what he sees: Oskar Schindler -- salesman from Zwit looking almost reputable in his one nice suit. Even in this awful room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A spotlight slicing across a crowded smoke-choked club to small stage where a cabaret performer sings. ItВ’s September, 1939. General Sigmund List's armored  divisions, driving north from the Sudetenland, have taken Cracow, and now, in this club, drinking, socializing,  conducting business, is a strange clientele: SS officers Polish cops, gangsters and girls and entrepreneurs, throw together by the circumstance of war. Oskar Schindler, drinking alone, slowly scans the room, t faces, stripping away all thatВ’s unimportant to him, set only on details that are: the rank of this man, the highe rank of that one, money being slipped into a hand.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER SETS DOWN DRINKS
dialogues.text: in front of the SS officer who took the money. A lieutena heВ’s at a table with his girlfriend and a lower-ranking  officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter is gesturing to a table across the room where  Schindler, seemingly unaware of the SS men, drinks with t best-looking woman in the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His sergeant doesnВ’t. His girlfriend doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find out who he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sergeant makes his way over to Schindler's table. There's a handshake and introductions before -- and the  lieutenant, watching, can't believe it -- his guy accepts the chair Schindler's dragging over. The lieutenant waits, but his man doesn't come back; he's forgotten already he went there for a reason. Finally, an it irritates the SS man, he has to get up and go over the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His girlfriend watches him cross toward Schindler's table Before he even arrives, Schindler is up and berating him leaving his date way over there across the room, waving a the girl to come join them, motioning to waiter to slide  some tables together.

dialogues.speaker: WAITERS ARRIVE WITH PLATES OF CAVIAR
dialogues.text: and another round of drinks. The lieutenant makes a  halfhearted move for his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me get this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, put it away, put it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler's already got his money out. Even as he's payin his eyes are working the room, settling on a table where girl is declining the advances of two more high-ranking S men.

dialogues.speaker: A TABLECLOTH BILLOWS
dialogues.text: as a waiter lays it down on another table that's been add to the others. Schindler seats the SS officers on either  side of his own "date" --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you drinking, gin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He motions to a waiter to refill the men's drinks, and,  returning to the head of the table(s), sweeps the room ag with his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ROAR OF LAUGHTER
dialogues.text: erupts from Schindler's party in the corner. Nobody's hav a better time than those people over there. His guests ha swelled to ten or twelve -- SS men, Polish cops, girls -- and he moves among them like the great entertainer he is, making sure everybody's got enough to eat and drink. Here, closer, at this table across the room, an SS office gestures to one of the SS men who an hour ago couldn't ge the girl to sit at his table. The guy comes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like everyone knows) That's Oskar Schindler. He's an old  friend of... I don't know, somebody's.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL WITH A BIG CAMERA
dialogues.text: screws in a flashbulb. She lifts the unwieldy thing to he face and focuses. As the bulb flashes, the noise of the club suddenly drops out, and the moment is caught in BLACK and WHITE: Oskar  Schindler, surrounded by his many new friends, smiling  urbanely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A photograph of a face on a work card, BLACK and WHITE. A typed name, black and white. A hand affixes a sticker to card and it saturates with COLOR, DEEP BLUE. People in long lines, waiting. Others near idling trucks, waiting. Others against sides of buildings, waiting. Cler with clipboards move through the crowds, calling out name

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Groder... Gemeinerowa... Libeskind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party pin in his lapel catches the light in the hallw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind Schindler, the door to another apartment closes so A radio, somewhere, is suddenly silenced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Itzhak Stern?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the door of this apartment, a man with the face and ma of a Talmudic scholar, finally nods in resignation, like number has just come up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler offers a hand. Confused, Stern tentatively reac for it, and finds his own grasped firmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Settled into an overstuffed chair in a simple apartment,  Schindler pours a shot of cognac from a flask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a company you did the books  for on Lipowa Street, made what,  pots and pans?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern stares at the cognac Schindler's offering him. He  doesn't know who this man is, or what he wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) By law, I have to tell you, sir, I'm  a Jew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler looks puzzled, then shrugs, dismissing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, you've done it -- good  company, you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He keeps holding out the drink. Stern declines it with a  slow shake of his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It did all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler nods, takes out a cigarette case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know anything about  enamelware, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He offers Stern a cigarette. Stern declines again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just the accountant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simple engineering, though, wouldn't  you think? Change the machines around,  whatever you do, you could make other  things, couldn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler lowers his voice as if there could possibly be  someone else listening in somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Field kits, mess kits...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waits for a reaction, and misinterprets Stern's silenc for a lack of understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Army contracts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Stern does understand. He understands too well. Schindler grins good-naturedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once the war ends, forget it, but  for now it's great, you could make a  fortune. Don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with an edge) I think most people right now have  other priorities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler tries for a moment to imagine what they could  possibly be. He can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern smiles despite himself. The man's manner is so simp so in contrast to his own and the complexities of being a Jew in occupied Cracow in 1939. He really doesn't know. S decides to end the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the contracts and I'm sure you'll  do very well. In fact the worse things  get the better you'll do. It was a  "pleasure."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The contracts? That's the easy part.  Finding the money to buy the company,  that's hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs loudly, uproariously. But then, just as abruptl as the laugh erupted, he's dead serious, all kidding asid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know anybody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern stares at him curiously, sitting there taking anoth sip of his cognac, placid as a large dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jews, yeah. Investors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Jews can no longer own businesses,  sir, that's why this one's for sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they wouldn't own it, I'd own  it. I'd pay them back in product.  They can trade it on the black market,  do whatever they want, everybody's  happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shrugs; it sounds more than fair to him. But not to St

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pots and pans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Something they can hold in their  hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern studies him. This man is nothing more than a salesm with a salesman's pitch; just dressed better than most.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know anybody who'd be  interested in that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a slow knowing nod) They should be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mason trowels mortar onto a brick. As he taps it into a place and scrapes off the excess cement, the image DRAINS COLOR. Under lights, a crew of brick-layers is erecting a ten-fo wall where a street once ran unimpeded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young man emerges from an alley pocketing his Jewish  armband. He crosses a street past German soldiers and tru and climbs the steps of St. Mary's cathedral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark and cavernous place. A priest performing Mass to  scattered parishioners. Lots of empty pews. The young Polish Jew from the street, Poldek Pfefferberg, kneels, crosses himself, and slides in next to another yo man, Goldberg, going over notes scribbled on a little pad inside a missal. Pfefferberg shows him a container of sho polish he takes from his pocket. Whispered, bored --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't recognize it? Maybe that's  because it's not what I asked for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You asked for shoe polish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My buyers sold it to a guy who sold  it to the Army. But by the time it  got there -- because of the cold --  it broke, the whole truckload.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) So I'm responsible for the weather?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked for metal, you gave me glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not my problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goldberg doesn't bother; he pockets his little notepad an intones a response to the priest's prayer, all but ignori Pfefferberg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not your problem? Everybody  wants to know who I got it from, and  I'm going to tell them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goldberg glances to Pfefferberg for the first time, and,  greatly put upon, takes out his little notepad again and  makes a notation in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Metal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flips the pad closed, pockets it, crosses himself as h gets up, and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pfefferberg at the front desk of a sleepy hotel with anot black market middleman, the desk clerk. Both are wearing  their armbands. Pfefferberg underlines figures on a littl notepad of his own --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's say this is what you give me.  These are fees I have to pay some  guys. This is my commission. This is  what I bring you back in Occupation  currency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk, satisfied with the figures, is about to hand o to Pfefferberg some outlawed Polish notes from an envelop when Schindler comes in from the street. The clerk puts t money away, gets Schindler his room key, waits for him to leave so he can finish his business with Pfefferberg... b Schindler doesn't leave; he just keeps looking over at  Pfefferberg's shirt, at the cuffs, the collar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a nice shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pfefferberg nods, Yeah, thanks, and waits for Schindler t leave; but he doesn't. Nor does he appear to hear the sho burst of muffled gunfire that erupts from somewhere up th street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know where I could find a  shirt like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pfefferberg knows he should say 'no,' let that be the end it. It's not wise doing business with a German who could  have you arrested for no reason whatsoever. But there's  something guileless about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) There's nothing in the stores.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk tries to discourage Pfefferberg from pursuing t transaction with just a look. Pfefferberg ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have any idea what a shirt like  this costs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice things cost money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk tries to tell Pfefferberg again with a look tha this isn't smart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, ten or twelve. That's  a good color. Dark blues, grays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler takes out his money and begins peeling off bill waiting for Pfefferberg to nod when it's enough. He's bei overcharged, and he knows it, but Pfefferberg keeps pushi it, more. The look Schindler gives him lets him know that he's trying to hustle a hustler, but that, in this instan at least, he'll let it go. He hands over the money and  Pfefferberg hands over his notepad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Write down your measurements.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he writes down the information, Pfefferberg glances to the desk clerk and offers a shrug. As he writes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to need some other things.  As things come up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Oberfuhrer Scherner and his daughter, in a wedding gow dance to the music of a quartet on a bandstand, the recep guests drink and eat at tables set up on an expansive law

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SS doesn't own the trains,  somebody's got to pay. Whether it's  a passenger car or a livestock car,  it doesn't matter -- which, by the  way, you have to see. You have to  set aside an afternoon, go down to  the station and see this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other SS and Army officers share the table with Czurda. Schindler, too, nice blue shirt, jacket, only he doesn't  seem to be paying attention; rather his attention and  affections are directed to the blonde next to him, Ingrid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you got thousands of fares that  have to be paid. Since it's the SS  that's reserved the trains, logically  they should pay. But this is a lot  of money. (pause) The Jews. They're the ones riding  the trains, they should pay. So you  got Jews paying their own fares to  ride on cattle cars to God knows  where. They pay the SS full fare,  the SS turns around, pays the railroad  a reduced excursion fare, and pockets  the difference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shrugs, There you have it. Brilliant. He glances off,  sees something odd across the yard. Two horses, saddled-u being led into the garden by a stable boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ingrid) Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler gets up from the table. Scherner, his wife and  daughter and son-in-law stare at the horses; they're  beautiful. Schindler appears, takes the reins from the stable boy, h one set to the bride and the other to the groom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing more sacred than  marriage. No happier an occasion  than one's wedding day. I wish you  all the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scherner hails a photographer. As the guy comes over with his camera, so does just about everybody else. Scherner  insists Schindler pose with the astonished bride and groo Big smiles. Flash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A neighborhood place. Bread, pastries, couple of tables. one sits owner and a well-dressed man in his seventies, M Redlicht.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I go to the bank, I go in, they tell  me my account's been placed in Trust.  In Trust? What are they talking about,  whose Trust? The Germans'. I look  around. Now I see that everybody's  arguing, they can't get to their  money either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take you there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max looks at the man not without sympathy. He's never hea of such a thing. It's really a bad deal. But then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me understand. The Nazis have  taken your money. So because they've  done this to you, you expect me to  go unpaid. That's what you're saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The owner of the place just stares at Redlicht.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That makes sense to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man doesn't answer. He watches Max get up and cross t the front door where he says something to two of his guys and leaves. The guys come in and start carting out anythi of any value: cash register, a chair, a loaf of bread...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max strolls along the sidewalk, browsing in store windows People inside and out nod hello, but they despise him, th fear him. Just as he's passing a synagogue, some men in long overco cross the street. Einsatzgruppen, they are an elite and w bunch, one of six Special Chivalrous Duty squads assigned Cracow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sabbath prayers of a congregation of Orthodox Jews ar interrupted by a commotion at the rear of the ancient tem Several non-Orthodox Jews from the street, including Max  Redlicht, are being herded inside by the Einsatz Boys. They're made to stand before the Ark in two lines: Orthod and non. One of the Einsatzgruppen squad removes the parc Torah scroll while another calmly addresses the assembly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to spit on it. I want you  to walk past, spit on it, and stand  over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one does anything for a moment. The liberals from the  street seem to say with their eyes, Come on, we're all to sophisticated for this; the others, with the beards and  sidelocks, silently check with their rabbi. One by one then they file past and spit on the scroll. Th last two, the rabbi and Max Redlicht hesitate. They excha a glance. The rabbi finally does it; the gangster doesn't After a long tense silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't been to temple must be  fifty years. (to the rabbi) Nor have I been invited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Einsatz NCO glances from Max to the rabbi and smiles himself. This is unexpected, this rift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the rabbi) You don't approve of the way I make  my living? I'm a bad man, I do bad  things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max admits it with a shrug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done some things... but I won't  do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. The Einsatz NCO glances away to the others, amus

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does this mean? Of all of you,  there's only one who has the guts to  say no? One? And he doesn't even  believe? (no one, of course  answer him) I come in here, I ask you to do  something no one should ever ask.  And you do it? (pause) What won't you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody answers. He turns to Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, sir, I respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls out a revolver and shoots the old gangster in th head. He's dead before he hits the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rest of you... ...are beneath  his contempt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and walks away. The other Einsatz Boys pull rifl and revolvers from their coats and open fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In BLACK AND WHITE and absolute silence, a suitcase throw from a second story window arcs slowly through the air. A it hits the pavement, spilling open -- SOUND ON -- and,  returning to COLOR -- Thousands of families pushing barrows through the streets Kazimierz, dragging mattresses over the bridge at Podgorz carrying kettles and fur coats and children on a mass for exodus into the ghetto. Crowds of Poles line the sidewalks like spectators on a p route. Some wave. Some take it more soberly, as if sensin they may be next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Jews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little folding tables have been dragged out and set u again, and at them sit the clerks. Goldberg, of all people, has somehow managed to elevate  himself to a station of some authority. Armed with someth more frightening than a gun -- a clipboard -- he abets th Gestapo in their task of deciding who passes through the  ghetto gate and who detours to the train station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pfefferberg, with his wife Mila, at the head of a line th seems to stretch back forever, flicks at Goldberg's OD ar with disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ghetto Police. I'm a policeman now,  can you believe it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They consider each other for a long moment before Pfeffer leads his wife past Goldberg and into the ghetto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dismayed by each others' close proximity, Orthodox and li Jews wait to use the floor's single bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the next apartment comes the liturgical solo of a ca In this apartment, looking like they can't bear much more it, sit some non-Orthodox businessmen, Stern and Schindle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For each thousand you invest, you  take from the loading dock five  hundred kilos of product a month --  to begin in July and to continue for  one year -- after which time, we're  even. (he shrugs) That's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lets them think about it, pours a shot of cognac from flask, offers it to Stern, who brought this group togethe and now sits at Schindler's side. The accountant declines

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not good enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not good enough? Look where you're  living. Look where you've been put.  "Not good enough." (he almost laughs at  the squalor) A couple of months ago, you'd be  right. Not anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money's still money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it isn't, that's why we're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler lights a cigarette and waits for their answer. doesn't come. Just a silence. Which irritates him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I call this meeting? You told  Mr. Stern you wanted to speak to me.  I'm here. Now you want to negotiate?  The offer's withdrawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He caps his flask, pockets it, reaches for his top coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do we know you'll do what you  say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I said I would. What do you  want, a contract? To be filed where? (he slips into his  coat) I said what I'll do, that's our  contract.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The investors study him. This is not a manageable German. Whether he's honest or not is impossible to say. Their gl to Stern don't help them; he doesn't know either. The silence in the room is filled by the muffled singing  next door. One of the men eventually nods, He's in. Then  another. And another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A red power button is pushed, starting the motor of a hug metal press. The machine whirs, louder, louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler, at a wall of a windows, is peering down at the lone technician making adjustments to the machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The standard SS rate for Jewish  skilled labor is seven Marks a day,  five for unskilled and women. This  is what you pay the Economic Office,  the laborers themselves receive  nothing. Poles you pay wages.  Generally, they get a little more.  Are you listening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler turns from the wall of glass to face his new  accountant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that about the SS, the rate,  the... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jewish worker's salary, you pay  it directly to the SS, not to the  worker. He gets nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's less. It's less than what I  would pay a Pole. That's the point  I'm trying to make. Poles cost more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern hesitates, then nods. The look on Schindler's face  says, Well, what's to debate, the answer's clear to any f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should I hire Poles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another machine starting up, growling louder, louder --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To a yellow identity card with a sepia photograph a Germa clerk attaches a blue sticker, the holy Blauschein, proof that the carrier is an essential worker. At other folding tables other clerks pass summary judgment on hundreds of  ghetto dwellers standing in long lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man tries to hand over documentation supporting the c along with his Kennkarte to a German clerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not essential work, stand over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over there, other "non-essential people" are climbing ont trucks bound for unknown destinations. The teacher reluct relinquishes his place in line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The teacher at the head of the line again, but this time  with Stern at his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a metal polisher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands over a piece of paper. The clerk takes a look, i satisfied with it, brushes glue on the back of a Blausche and sticks it to the man's work card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world's gone mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another machine starting up, a lathe. A technician points things out to the teacher and some others recruited by St The motor grinds louder, louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler wanders around a large empty apartment. There's lots of light, glass bricks, modern lines, windows lookin out on a park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same place full of furniture and people. Lots of SS i uniform. Wine. Girls. Schindler, drinking with Oberfuhrer Scherner, keeps glancing across the room to a particularl good-looking Polish girl with another guy in uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd never ask you for money, you  know that. I don't even like talking  about it -- money, favors -- I find  it very awkward, it makes me very  uncomfortable --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, look. It's the others. They're  the ones causing these delays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What others?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoever. They're the ones. They'd  appreciate some kind of gesture from  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scherner thinks he understands what Schindler's saying. J in case he doesn't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should send it to you, though,  don't you think? You can forward it  on? I'd be grateful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scherner nods. Yes, they understand each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'd be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Done. Let's not talk about it anymore,  let's have a good time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scherner at his desk initialing several Armaments contrac The letters D.E.F. appear on all of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men and pulleys hoist a big "F" up the side of the buildi Down below, Schindler watches as the letter is set into p D.E.F.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The good-looking Polish girl from the party, Klonowska, i shown to her desk by Stern. It's right outside Schindler' office. This girl has never typed in her life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flames ignite with a whoosh in one of the huge furnaces. needle on a gauge slowly climbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A garage door slides open revealing a gleaming black Merc Schindler steps past Pfefferberg and, moving around the c carefully touches its smooth lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another machine starts up. Another. Another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern with a woman at the head of a line. The clerk affix the all-important blue sticker to her work card.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FACTORY DAY
dialogues.text: Three hundred Jewish laborers, men and women, work at the long tables, at the presses, the latches, the furnaces,  turning out field kitchenware and mess kits. Few glance up from their work at Schindler, the big gold  party pin stuck into his lapel, as he moves through the p his place, his factory, in full operation. He climbs the stairs to the offices where several secreta process Armaments orders. He gestures to Stern, at a desk covered with ledgers, to join him in his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The accountant follows Schindler into the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler goes to the wall of windows, his favorite place the world, and looks down at all the activity below. He p two drinks from a decanter and, turning back, holds one o to Stern. Stern, of course, declines. Schinder groans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes over and puts the drink in Stern's hand, moves b his desk and sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father was fond of saying you  need three things in life. A good  doctor, a forgiving priest and a  clever accountant. The first two...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dismisses them with a shrug; he's never had much use f either. But the third -- he raises his glass to the  accountant. Stern's glass stays in his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (long sufferingly) Just pretend for Christ's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern slowly raises his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler drinks; Stern doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Klonowska, wearing a man's silk robe, traipses past the  remains of a party to the front door. Opening it reveals nice looking, nicely dressed woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A series of realizations is made by each of them, quickly silently, ending up with Klonowska looking ill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler sets a cup of coffee down in front of his wife. Behind him, through a doorway, Klonowska can be seen hurr gathering her things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's so embarrassed -- look at her --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilie begrudges him a glance to the bedroom, catching th girl just as she looks up -- embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what, you'd like her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oskar, please --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have to like her just because  you do. It doesn't work that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would, though. That's what I'm  saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face is complete innocence. It's the first thing she  fell in love with; and perhaps the thing that keeps her f killing him now. Klonowska emerges from the bedroom thoro self-conscious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye. It was a pleasure meeting  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes Emilie's limp hand. Schindler sees her to the  door, lets her out and returns to the table, smiling to  himself. Emilie's glancing around at the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've done well here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods; he's proud of it. He studies her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They emerge from the building in formal clothes, both of  them looking great. It's wet and slick; the doorman offer Emilie his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful of the pavement --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Mrs. Schindler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doorman shoots a glance to Schindler that asks, clear Really? Schindler opens the passenger door of the Mercede for his wife, and the doorman helps her in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nice place. "No Jews or Dogs Allowed." The maitre 'd  welcomes the couple warmly, shakes Schindler's hand. Nodd to his date --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Schindler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The maitre 'd tries to bury his surprise. He's almost  successful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No fewer than four waiters attend them -- refilling a gla sliding pastries onto china, lighting Schindler's cigaret raking crumbs from the table with little combs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a charade, all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A charade? How could it be a charade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't know, but she does know him. And all these si of apparent success just don't fit his profile. Schindler lets her in on a discovery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no way I could have known  this before, but there was always  something missing. In every business  I tried, I see now it wasn't me that  was failing, it was this thing, this  missing thing. Even if I'd known  what it was, there's nothing I could  have done about it, because you can't  create this sort of thing. And it  makes all the difference in the world  between success and failure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waits for her to guess what the thing is. His looks sa It's so simple, how can you not know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: War.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Gloomy Sunday" from a combo on a stage. Schindler and Em dancing. Pressed against her -- both have had a few -- he can feel her laugh to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like an old-fashioned couple.  It feels good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles, even as his eyes roam the room and find and me the eyes of a German girl dancing with another man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler and Emilie lounging in bed, champagne bottle on the nightstand. Long silence before --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I stay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) It's a beautiful city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the answer she's looking for and he knows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I stay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) It's up to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not it either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's up to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler stares out at the lights of the city. They look like jewels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise me no doorman or maitre 'd  will presume I am anyone other than  Mrs. Schindler... and I'll stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He promises her nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilie waves goodbye to him from a first-class compartmen window. Down on the platform, he waves goodbye to her. as the train pulls away, he turns away, and the platform of next track is revealed -- soldiers and clerks supervising the boarding of hundreds of people onto another train -- image turning BLACK AND WHITE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your luggage will follow you. Make  sure it's clearly labeled. Leave  your luggage on the platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As workers load crates of enamelware onto trucks -- back COLOR -- Stern and Schindler and the dock foreman confer  over an invoice. More to Stern --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every other time it's been all right.  This time when I weigh the truck, I  see he's heavy, he's loaded too much.  I point this out to him, I tell him  to wait, he tells me he's got a new  arrangement with Mr. Schindler -- (to Schindler) -- that you know all about it and  it's okay with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's "okay" with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the surface, Schindler remains calm; underneath, he's  livid. Clearly it's not "okay" with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How heavy was he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that much, just too much for it  to be a mistake -- 200 kilos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern and Schindler exchange a glance. Then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) You're sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The foreman nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pfefferberg and Schindler bang in through the front door, startling a woman at a desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move past her without a word and into the back of th place, into a storeroom. They stride past long racks full enamelware and other goods. A man glances up, sees them coming. He's one of Schindler investors, the one who questioned the German's word. The  man's teenage sons rush to their father's defense, but  Pfefferberg grabs him and locks an arm tightly around his neck. Silence. Then, calmly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you or anyone acting as an agent  for you comes to my factory again,  I'll have you arrested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a mistake? What was a mistake?  How do you know what I'm talking  about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, it wasn't a mistake, but  it was one time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had a deal, you broke it. One  phone call and your whole family is  dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and walks away. Pfefferberg lets the guy go and  follows. The investor's sons help their father up off the floor. Gasping, he yells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave you money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- but Schindler and Pfefferberg are already gone, coming through the front office and out the front door --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- to the street. Pfefferberg looks a little shaken from experience. Schindler straightens his friend's clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you feeling, all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, everything all  right at home? (Pfefferberg nods) Mila's okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then, Schindler can't imagine what could be wrong. pats Pfefferberg on the shoulder and leads him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The long tables accommodate most of workers. The rest eat their lunch on the floor. Soup and bread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An elegant place setting for one. Meat, vegetables, glass wine, all untouched. Schindler leafing through pages of a report Stern has prepared for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could try to read this or I could  eat my lunch while it's till hot.  We're doing well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better this month than last?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any reason to think next month will  be worse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The war could end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No chance of that. Satisfied, Schindler returns the repor to his accountant and starts to eat. Stern knows he is  excused, but looks like he wants to say something more; h just doesn't know how to say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatient) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) There's a machinist outside who'd  like to thank you personally for  giving him a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler gives his accountant a long-suffering look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He asks every day. It'll just take a  minute. He's very grateful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler's silence says, Is this really necessary? Stern pretends it's a tacit okay, goes to the door and pokes hi head out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Lowenstein?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old man with one arm appears in the doorway and Schind glances to the ceiling, to heaven. As the man slowly make his way into the room, Schindler sees the bruises on his  face. And when he speaks, only half his mouth moves; the  other half is paralyzed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to thank you, sir, for giving  me the opportunity to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome, I'm sure you're doing  a great job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler shakes the man's hand perfunctorily and tells S with a look, okay, that's enough, get him out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SS beat me up. They would have  killed me, but I'm essential to the  war effort, thanks to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I work hard for you. I'll continue  to work hard for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God bless you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a good man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler is dying, and telling Stern with his eyes, Get  this guy out of here. Stern takes the man's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Mr. Lowenstein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He saved my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, he did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God bless him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They disappear out the door. Schindler sits down to his m And tries to eat it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern and Schindler emerge from the rear of the factory. Mercedes is waiting, the back door held open by a driver. Climbing in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ever do that to me again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern knows what he means. And Schindler knows he knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow on the ground and more coming down. A hundred of  Schindler's workers marching past the ghetto gate, as is custom, under armed guard. Turning onto Zablocie Street,  they're halted by an SS unit standing around some trucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shovels scraping at snow. The marchers working to clear i from the street. A dialog between one of the guards and a SS officer is interrupted by a shot -- and the face of th one-armed machinist falls into the frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herman Toffel, an SS contact of Schindler's who he actual likes, sits behind his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's got nothing to do with reality,  Oskar, I know it and you know it,  it's a matter of national priority  to these guys. It's got a ritual  significance to them, Jews shoveling  snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lost a day of production. I lost a  worker. I expect to be compensated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: File a grievance with the Economic  Office, it's your right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would it do any good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler knows it's not Toffel's fault, but the whole  situation is maddening to him. He shakes his head in disg

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're going to have to put  up with a lot of snow shoveling yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler gets up, shakes Toffel's hand, turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A one-armed machinist, Oskar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (right back) He was a metal press operator, quite  skilled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toffel nods, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a distance, Stern and Schindler slowly walk a wastel that lies between the rear of DEF and two other factories a radiator works and a box plant. Stern's doing all the talking, in his usual quiet but  persuasive manner. Every so often, Schindler, glancing fr his own factory to the others, nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party pins the two other German businessmen wear are  nothing compared to the elaborate thing in Schindler's la He sits at his desk sipping cognac, a large portrait of H hanging prominently on the wall behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unlike your radiators -- and your  boxes -- my products aren't for sale  on the open market. This company has  only one client, the German Army.  And lately I've been having trouble  fulfilling my obligations to my  client. With your help, I hope the  problem can be solved. The problem,  simply, is space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern, who has been keeping a low profile, hands the gent each a set of documents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like you to consider a proposal  which I think you'll find equitable.  I'd like you to think about it and  get back to me as soon as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me -- do you really think  this is appropriate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man glances to Stern, and back to Schindler, his look saying, This is wrong, having a Jew present while we disc business. If Schindler catches his meaning, he doesn't ad it. Kuhnpast almost sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can appreciate your problem. If I  had any space I could lease you, I  would. I don't. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me neither, sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to lease your facilities,  I want to buy them. I'm prepared to  offer you fair market value. And to  let you stay on, if you want, as  supervisors. (pause) On salary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a long stunned silence. The Germans can't believe it. After the initial shock wears off, Kuhnpast has to la

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to be kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody is kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Thanks for the drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sets it down, gets up. Hohne gets up. They return the  documents to Stern and turn to leave. They aren't quite o the door when Schindler wonders out loud to Stern:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You try to be fair to people, they  walk out the door; I've never  understood that. What's next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christmas presents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The businessmen slow, but don't look back into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pfefferberg wipes a smudge from the hood of an otherwise  pristine BMW Cabriolet. As Scherner and his wife emerge f their house in robes, Scherner whispers to himself --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oskar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Workers high on the side of the building toss down the le of the radiator sign as others hoist up a big "D." Under  armed guard, others unload a metal press machine from a t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Technicians make adjustments to presses already in place. Others test the new firing ovens. Kuhnpast is being forci removed from the premises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowded beyond belief, the place is like a post office go mad. Stern, moving along one of the impossibly crowded li pauses to speak with an elderly couple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand slaps a blue sticker on a work card. Slap, another And another. And another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christmas decorations. Klonowska at her desk, her eyes cl tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens her eyes and smiles. Schindler is holding a poo in his arms. She comes around to kiss him. He sets the do on the desk. Stern, across the room, watches blank-faced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oskar Schindler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler, Stern and Klonowska turn to the voice. Two Ges men have entered unannounced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a warrant to take your  company's business records with us.  And another to take you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler stares at them in disbelief. Stern quietly slip one of the ledgers on his desk into a drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I permitted to have my secretary  cancel my appointments for the day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't wait for their approval. He scribbles down som names -- Toffel, Czurda, Reeder, Scherner. Underlining  Scherner, he glances to Klonowska. She understands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A humorless middle-level bureaucrat sits behind a desk an D.E.F.'s ledgers and cashbooks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You live very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man slowly shakes his head 'no' to Schindler's offer a cigarette. Schindler tamps it against the crystal of hi gold watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This standard of living comes entirely  from legitimate sources, I take it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler lights the cigarette and drags on it, all but  ignoring the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As an SS supplier, you have a moral  obligation to desist from blackmarket  dealings. You're in business to  support the war effort, not to fatten --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) You know? When my friends ask, I'd  love to be able to tell them you  treated me with the utmost courtesy  and respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The quiet matter-of-fact tone, more than the comment itse throws the bureaucrat off his rhythm. His eyes narrow  slightly. There's a long silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two who arrested him lead Schindler down a long hallw They reach a door, have him step inside and close the doo after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler knocks on the inside of the door. A Waffen SS m opens it. The "prisoner" peels several bills from a thick wad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chances of getting a bottle of vodka  pretty good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the young guard five times the going price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guard turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He peels off several more bills and hands them over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perched on the side of the bed in pajamas, Schindler work on a breakfast of herring and eggs, cheeses, rolls and co Someone has also brought him a newspaper. There's an  apologetic knock on the door before it opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to disturb you, sir.  Whenever you're ready, you're free  to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler, the Gestapo clerk and one of the arresting off cross the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd advise you not to get too  comfortable. Sooner or later, law  prevails. No matter who your friends  are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler ignores the man completely. Reaching the front  doors, the clerk turns over the D.E.F. records to their o and offers his hand. Schindler lets it hang there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You expect me to walk home, or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tightly) Bring a car around for Mr. Schindler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Gestapo limousine pulls in through the gates of the fac parks near the loading docks. The driver, the same SS off waits for Schindler to climb out, but he doesn't; he wait for the SS man to come around and open the door for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'd return the ledgers to my  office I'd appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no less than forty able-bodied Jewish laborers  working on the docks, any one of which would be better su to the task. The Gestapo man calls to one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me -- hey -- (the guy turns) They're working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy just stares. Finally he heads off with the ledger The poodle bounds out past him and over to Schindler. He  gives the dog a pat on the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elegantly dressed for a night out, Schindler and Klonowsk emerge from the building. As they're escorted to the wait car, Schindler hesitates. A nervous figure in the shadows an alcove is gesturing to him, beckoning him. Schindler excuses himself. Klonowska watches as he joins man in the alcove. Their whispered conversation is over  quickly and the man hurries off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the locomotive, looking back, the string of splatter livestock carriages stretches into darkness. There's a lo of activity on the platform. Guards mill. Handcards piled with luggage trundle by. People hand up children to others already in the cars and climb aboard after them. The clerks are out in full force with their lists and clipboards, reminding the travelers label their suitcases. Climbing from his Mercedes, Schindler stares. He's heard this, but actually seeing the juxtaposition -- human and  cattle cars -- this is something else. Recovering, he tells Klonowska to stay in the car and, mo along the side of the train, calls Stern's name to the fa peering out from behind the slats and barbed wire.

dialogues.speaker: AN ENORMOUS LIST OF NAMES --
dialogues.text: -- several pages-worth on a clipboard; a Gestapo clerk  methodically leafing through them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's essential. Without him,  everything comes to a grinding halt.  If that happens --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Itzhak Stern? (Schindler nods) He's on the list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk shows him the list, points out the name to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's find him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's on the list. If he were an  essential worker, he would not be on  the list. He's on the list. You can't  have him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking to a clerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler pulls out a small notepad and drops his voice t hard murmur, the growl of a reasonable man who isn't read yet -- to bring out his heavy guns:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, the list is correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't ask you about the list, I  asked you your name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Klaus Tauber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Schindler writes it down, the clerk has second thought and calls to a superior, an SS sergeant, who comes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gentleman thinks a mistake's  been made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My plant manager is somewhere on  this train. If it leaves with him on  it, it'll disrupt production and the  Armaments Board will want to know  why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sergeant takes a good hard look at the clothes, at th pin, at the man wearing them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the clerk) Is he on the list?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Schindler) The list is correct, sir. There's  nothing I can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May as well get your name while you're  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name? My name is Kunder. Sergeant  Kunder. What's yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sergeant takes out a pad. Now all three of them have  lists. He jots down Schindler's name. Schindler jots down his and flips the pad closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant, Mr. Tauber, thank you very  much. I think I can guarantee you  you'll both be in Southern Russia  before the end of the month. Good  evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks away, back toward his car. The clerk and sergean smile. But slowly, slowly, the smiles sour at the possibi that this man calmly walking away from them could somehow arrange such a fate...

dialogues.speaker: ALL THREE OF THEM --
dialogues.text: -- Schindler, the clerk and the sergeant -- stride along side of the cars. Two of them are calling out loudly -- CLERK & SERGEANT Stern! Itzhak Stern!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon it seems as if everybody except Schindler is yelling out the name. As they reach the last few cars, the  accountant's face appears through the slats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guards yank at a lever, slide the gate open. Stern climbs down. The clerk draws a line through his name on the list and hands the clipboard to Schindler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Initial it, please. (Schindler initials  the change) And this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Schindler signs three or four forms, the guards slide carriage gate closed. Those left inside seem grateful for the extra space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes no difference to us, you  understand -- this one, that one.  It's the inconvenience to the list.  It's the paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler returns the clipboard. The sergeant motions to  another who motions to the engineer. As the train pulls o Stern tries to keep up with Schindler who's striding away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I somehow left my work card at home.  I tried to tell them it was a mistake,  but they --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler silences him with a look. He's livid. Stern gla down at the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. It was stupid. (contrite) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler turns away and heads for the car. Stern hurries after him. They pass an area where all the luggage, caref tagged, has been left -- the image becoming BLACK and WHI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mechanics' hood-lamps throw down pools of light through w me wheel handcarts piled high with suitcases, briefcases, steamer trunks -- BLACK and WHITE. Moving along with one of the handcarts into a huge garage past racks of clothes, each item tagged, past musical  instruments, furniture, paintings, against one wall --  children's toys, sorted by size. The cart stops. A valise is handed to someone who dumps a sorts the contents on a greasy table. The jewelry is take to another area, to a pit, one of two deep lubrication ba filled with watches, bracelets, necklaces, candelabra,  Passover platters, gold in one, silver the other, and tos in. At workbenches, four Jewish jewelers under SS guard sift sort and weigh and grade diamonds, pearls, pendants, broo children's rings -- faltering only once, when a uniformed figure upends a box, spilling out gold teeth smeared with blood -- the image saturating with COLOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fractured gravestones like broken teeth jut from the eart of a neglected Jewish cemetery outside of town. Down the  road that runs alongside it comes a German staff car.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: In the backseat, Untersturmfuhrer Amon Goeth pulls on a f of schnapps. His age and build are about that of Schindle his face open and pleasant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make a nice driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other SS officers in the car -- Knude, Haase and Huja aren't sure what he means. He's peering out the window at the tombstones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The staff car passes through the portals of the ghetto an down the trolley lines of Lwowska Street.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: As the car slowly cruises through the ghetto, Knude, like tour guide, briefs the new man, Goeth --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This street divides the ghetto just  about in half. On the right -- Ghetto  A: civil employees, industry workers,  so on. On the left, Ghetto B: surplus  labor, the elderly mostly. Which is  where you'll probably want to start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The look Goeth gives Knude tells him to refrain, if he wo from offering tactical opinions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course that's entirely up to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside of town, a previously abandoned limestone quarry  lies nestled between two hills. The stone and brick build look like they've been here forever; the wooden structure those that are up, are built of freshly-cut lumber. There's a great deal of activity. New construction and  renovation -- foundations being poured, rail tracks being laid, fences and watchtowers going up, heavy segments of  huts -- wall panels, eaves sections -- being dragged uphi by teams of bescarved women like some ancient Egyptian  industry. Goeth surveys the site from a knoll, clearly pleased with it. But then he's distracted by voices -- a man's, a woman's arguing down where some barracks are being erected. The woman breaks off the dialog with a disgusted wave of hand and stalks back to a half-finished barracks. The man one from the car, Hujar, sees Goeth, Knude and Haase comi down the hill and moves to meet them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She says the foundation was poured  wrong, she's got to take it down. I  told her it's a barracks, not a  fucking hotel, fucking Jew engineer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth watches the woman moving around the shell of the  building, pointing, directing, telling the workers to tak it all down. He goes to take a closer look. She comes ove

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire foundation has to be dug  up and re-poured. If it isn't, the  thing will collapse before it's even  completed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth considers the foundation as if he knew about such  things. He nods pensively. Then turns to Hujar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) Shoot her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to tell which is more stunned by the order, the woman or Hujar. Both stare at Goeth in disbelief. He give her the reason along with a shrug --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You argued with my man. (to Hujar) Shoot her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hujar unholsters his pistol but holds it limply at his si The workers become aware of what's happening and still th hammers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth groans and takes the gun from him and puts it to th woman's head. Calmly to her --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fires. She crumples to the ground. He returns the gun his stunned inferior and, gesturing down at the body,  addresses the workers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's somebody who knew what they  were doing. That's somebody I needed. (pause) Take it down, re-pour it, rebuild  it, like she said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stable boys lead two horses into the pre-dawn light. The  animals' hoofs shatter tufts of weeds like fingers of gla fog plumes from their nostrils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In addition to the exhaust from idling trucks and the cur smoke from the Sonderkommando units' cigarettes, there is excitement in the chilly pre-dawn air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An empty street. Rooftops against a lightening sky. A few the windows in the buildings are lighted, glowing amber; majority are still dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stable boys hoist saddles onto the horses, cinch the  straps. Leaning against the hood of the Mercedes, Schindl and Ingrid, in long hacking jackets, riding breeches and  boots, share cognac from his flask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Untersturmfuhrer Goeth, soon to be Commandant Goeth, stan before the assembled troops with a flask of cognac in his hand. He looks out over them proudly; they're good boys,  these, the best. He addresses them --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today is history. The young will ask  with wonder about this day. Today is  history and you are a part of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fourteen year old kid hurries across to the square pull on his O.D. armband. Several others of the Jewish Ghetto  Police, Golberg among them, are already assembled there. clerks, the list makers, scissor open their folding table set out their ink pads and stamps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When, elsewhere, they were footing  the blame for the Black Death,  Kazimierz the Great, so called, told  the Jews they could come to Cracow.  They came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ingrid climbs onto one of the horses, Schindler onto the  other. As the animals gallop away with their riders towar wood, the stable boys wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They trundled their belongings into  this city, they settled, they took  hold, they prospered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fresh young faces of the Sonderkommandos, listening t their commander.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For six centuries, there has been a  Jewish Cracow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horses panting hard. Their hoofs hammering at the gro climbing a hill. Riding boots kicking at their flanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boots of Amon Goeth slowly pacing. He stops. Tight on his face, smiling pleasantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By this weekend, those six centuries,  they're a rumor. They never happened.  Today is history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The galloping horses break through to a clearing high on hill. The riders pull in the reins and the hoofs rip at t earth. Schindler smiles at the view, the beauty of it with the s just coming up. From here, all of Cracow can be seen in  striking relief, like a model of a town. He can see the Vistula, the river that separates the ghet from Kazimierz; Wawel Castle, from where the National  Socialist Party's Hans Frank rules the Government General Poland; beyond it, the center of town. He begins to notice refinements: the walls that define th ghetto; Peace Square, the assembly of men and boys. He no a line of trucks rolling east across the Kosciuscko Bridg and another across the bridge at Podgorze, a third along  Zablocie Street, all angling in on the ghetto like spokes a hub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wheels of the last truck clear the portals at Lwowska Street and the Sonderkommandos jump down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Families are routed from their apartments. An appeal to b allowed to pack is answered with a rifle butt; an unannou move to a desk drawer is countered with a shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spilling out of the buildings, they're herded into lines  without regard to family consideration; some other  unfathomable system is at work here. The wailing protests a woman to join her husband's line are abruptly cut off b short burst of gunfire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From here, the action down below seems staged, unreal; th rifle bursts no louder than caps. Dismounting, Schindler  moves closer to the edge of the hill, curious. His attention is drawn to a small distant figure, all in  red, at the rear of one of the many columns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small red shoes against a forest of gleaming black boots. Waffen SS man occasionally corrects the little girl's dri fraternally it seems, nudging her gently back in line wit the barrel of his rifle. A volley of shots echoes from up the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler watches as the girl slowly wanders away unnotic by the SS. Against the grays of the buildings and street  she's like a moving red target.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A truck thundering down the street obscures her for a mom Then she's moving past a pile of bodies, old people execu in the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler watches: she's so conspicuous, yet she keeps mo past crowds, past dogs, past trucks -- as though she were invisible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patients in white gowns, and doctors and nurses in white, are herded out the doors of a convalescent hospital. The  small figure in red moves past them. Shots explode behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Short bursts of light flash throughout the ghetto like st Schindler, fixated on the figure in red, loses sight of h as she turns a corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She climbs the stairs. The building is empty. She steps i an apartment and moves through it. It's been ransacked. A she crawls under the bed, the scene DRAINS of COLOR. The gunfire outside sounds like firecrackers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIGHT Silence. Schindler and Ingrid are gone. Below, the ghetto lies like a void within the city, its  perimeter and interior clearly distinguishable by darknes Outside it, the lights of the rest of Cracow glimmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tables and tools and enamelware scrap. The metal presses lathes, still. The firing ovens, cold. The gauges at zero Against the wall of windows overlooking the empty factory floor stands a figure, Schindler, in silhouette against t glass, black against white, not moving, just staring down

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody wheelbarrows, stark against the tree line of a for above the completed forced labor camp, PLASZOW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Names on lists. Names called out. Tight on faces. Goldberg at one of several folding tables. The gangstertu ghetto-cop is now the Lord of Lists inside Plaszow. He and other listmakers call out names, accounting for th thousands who survived the liquidation of the ghetto and stand before them in long straight rows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amon Goeth stirs, wakes, glances at the woman asleep besi him. Hungover, he drags himself slowly out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth steps out onto the balcony in his undershirt and sh and peers out across the labor camp, his labor camp, his  kingdom. Satisfied with it, even amazed, he's reminiscent Schindler looking down on his kingdom, his factory, as he loves to do, from his wall of glass. Life is great. Goeth reaches for a rifle.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PLASZOW SAME TIME
dialogues.text: Workers loading quarry rock onto trolleys under Ukrainian guard and a low morning sun. Every so often, one glances  with anticipation to the balcony of Goeth's "villa" -- wh is in fact nothing more than a two-story stone house perc on a slight rise in the dry landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The butt of the rifle against his shoulder, Goeth aims do at the quarry -- at this worker, at that one --  indiscriminately, inscrutably. He fires a shot and a dist figure falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman in bed groans at the echoing shot. She's used t it but she still hates it; it's such an awful way to be w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mutters) Amon... Christ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She buries her head under a pillow. Goeth reappears. He p to his bathroom, goes inside and urinates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler's Mercedes winds through the camp, past warehou and workshops, trucks full of furs and furniture, work  details, barracks, guard blocks. A man standing alone wea a sign around his neck -- "I am a potato thief."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mercedes pulls in next to some other nice cars parked a driveway made of tombstones from the Jewish cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A patio table set with crystal, china, silver. Goeth and  Hujar are there, in pressed SS uniforms, and two  industrialists, Bosch and Madritsch. One chair is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your machinery will be moved and  installed by the SS at no cost to  you. You will pay no rent, no  maintenance --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hujar glances off, interrupted by Schindler's arrival. Although he's never been here, the industrialist comes in like he owns the place. All but Goeth rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, come on, sit --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He works his way around the table, patting Bosch and Madr on the back -- he knows them -- shaking Hujar's hand, who doesn't know. He reaches Goeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth takes a good long look at the handsomely dressed  entrepreneur and allows him to shake his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We started without you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler takes a seat, shakes a napkin onto his lap, nod to the servant holding out a bottle of champagne to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth watches him. The others watch Goeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I miss anything important?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
