dialogues.text: I was explaining to Mr. Bosch and  Mr. Madritsch some of the benefits  of moving their factories into  Plaszow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, good, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler clearly doesn't care, but nods as though he did He drinks. Goeth just watches him with what seems to be  growing amusement. He nods to Hujar to continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since your labor is housed on-site,  it's available to you at all times.  You can work them all night if you  want. Your factory policies, whatever  they've been in the past, they'll  continue to be, they'll be respected --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler laughs out loud, cutting Hujar off. Hujar glanc over to Goeth nonplussed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not sorry at all, and starts in on the plate of food that's set down in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, they told me you were going  to be trouble -- Czurda and Scherner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth slowly shakes his head no... then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks great, though, doesn't he?  I have to know -- where do you get a  suit like that? what is that, silk? (Schindler nods) It's great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say I'd get you one but the guy  who made it, he's probably dead, I  don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shrugs like, those are the breaks, too bad. Goeth just smiles. The others watch the two of them, unsure how they supposed to react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others have gone. It's just Goeth and Schindler now. Goeth pours glasses of cognac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something wonderful's happened, do  you know what it is? Without planning  it, we've reached that happy point  in our careers where duty and  financial opportunity meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler nods pensively, perhaps in agreement, perhaps a some other thought. There's a silence, broken finally by

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I go to work the other day, there's  nobody there. Nobody tells me about  this, I have to find out, I have to  go in, everybody's gone --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not gone, they're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're mine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His voice echoes into silence. An acquiescent shrug from  Goeth finally. And a nod; Schindler's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every day that goes by, I'm losing  money. Every worker that is shot,  costs me money -- I have to get  somebody else, I have to train them --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to be making so much  money, none of this is going to matter --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) It's bad business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Some of the boys went crazy, what're  you going to do? You're right, it's  bad business, but it's over with,  it's done. (pause) Occasionally, sure, okay, you got to  make an example. But that's good  business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler pours himself another shot from the bottle, nur it. He's in a foul mood. They study each other, trying to determine perhaps who's more powerful. Eventually --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scherner told me something else about  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, what's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That you know the meaning of the  word gratitude. That it's not some  vague thing with you like with some  guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: True.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth tries to put the situation in perspective:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to stay where you are. You  got things going on the side, things  are good, you don't want anybody  telling you what to do -- I can  understand all that. (pause) What you want is your own sub-camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler admits it by not disagreeing. Goeth thinks abou it, nods to himself again, then frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea what's involved?  The paperwork alone? Forget you got  to build it all, getting the fucking  permits, that's enough to drive you  crazy. Then the engineers show up.  They stand around and they argue  about drainage -- I'm telling you,  you'll want to shoot somebody, I've  been through it, I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you've been through it. You  know. You could make things easier  for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth mulls it over, his shrug saying "maybe, maybe not." silence before --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be grateful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's the word Goeth was waiting to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An SS surveyor, with even paces, measures a distance of t bare field adjacent to the factory. He sticks a little fl into the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A watchtower, half-erected, the little flag still in the  ground. Laborers hammer at it while others roll out barbe wire fencing. A surveyor supervises the placement of a po and carefully measures its heights; it has to be nine fee exactly. At a folding table in the middle of the field, Schindler  signs checks made out to the Construction Office, Plaszow requisitioning more lumber, cement and hardware.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plaszow prisoners load the requisitioned building supplie the lumber, cement and hardware -- onto trucks.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. WAREHOUSE, CRACOW
dialogues.text: The trucks parked not at Schindler's sub-camp, but at the loading dock of Goeth's private warehouse in Cracow. Insi the building can be glimpsed all kinds of Plaszow goods:  clothes, food, construction equipment, furniture. Checkbook laid out on the hood of his Mercedes, Schindler pays for the requested materials a second time -- this ti with a check made out to Amon Goeth personally -- and han it over to his bagman, Hujar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some SS architects groan over a set of blueprints. Schind and an SS officer walk by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have the Poles beat the Czechs,  you have the Czechs beat the Poles,  that way everybody stays in line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I have is Jews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shrugs, Too bad, what're you going to do? The SS guy h to think. Yeah, that's a problem. Two huge leashed dogs y another SS man across their path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As five hundred Plaszow prisoners are marched back onto t grounds of D.E.F., any hope they may have had of a more  lenient environment is quickly dashed. The place -- compl looks like a fortress: barbed-wire, towers, SS guards and dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where once they glimpsed the not too threatening figure o Oskar Schindler strolling through the factory, the worker who dare glance up now find armed guards moving past. And further up, behind the wall of windows, Schindler moving  around, entertaining SS officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rosner brothers in evening clothes, Leo on accordion, Henry on violin, playing a Strauss melody, trying to keep muted, inoffensive. Few of the guests pay attention, whic is fine with them. An SS officer chats with Schindler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- she's seventy years old, she's  been there forever -- they bomb her  house. Everything's gone. The  furniture, everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (well aware the man  is lying) Thank God she wasn't there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler, with yet another girl on his arm, endures the  officer's lies while sweeping the room with his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking maybe you could help  her out. Some plates and mugs, some  stew pots, I don't know. Say half a  gross of everything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler looks at him for the first time, knowingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She run an orphanage, your aunt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's old. What she can't use maybe  she can sell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler's girl excuses herself to get a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want it sent directly to her or  through you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through me, I think. I'd like to  enclose a card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler nods, Done. Both watch his date across the room getting a drink. As usual, she's the best-looking on ther

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your wife must be a saint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever tolerance Schindler's had up to this point with  John leaves his face; the looks he gives him now is pure  contempt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth's girl tonight, a Pole, eighteen, nineteen, places hand on Schindler's sleeve. They're at the important end the large table with Goeth, along with Czurda and Leo Joh and their girlfriends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not a soldier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a picture. Private Schindler?  Blanket around his shoulders over in  Kharkov?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happened to what's his name -- up in  Warsaw -- and he was bigger than  you, Oskar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toebbens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happened to Toebbens. Almost. Himmler  goes up to Warsaw, tells the armament  guys, "Get the fucking Jews out of  Toebbens' factory and put Toebbens  in the army," and -- "and sent him  to the Front." I mean, the Front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true. Never happen in Cracow,  though, we all love you too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pay you too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another round of laughs, only this time it's forced. Everybody knows it's true, but you don't say it out loud, and Schindler knows better. Goeth gives him a look; they' talk later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth finds Schindler alone outside smoking a cigarette.  Schindler acknowledges him, but that's about it. Finally

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You held back Stern. You held back  the one man most important to my  business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's important to my business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want for him, I'll give  it to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want him. (turning back) Come on, let's go inside, let's have  a good time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth heads back inside. Schindler stays outside, finishi his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A folding table outside the prisoners' barracks. At it,  playing cards, two night sentries. A figure appears out o the darkness. Schindler. He sets down on the table a fift of vodka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern, summoned from his barracks, watches as Schindler d through his coat pockets. Nearby, at the table, drinking  now, the sentries. From the hill, the villa, the Rosners' music, faint, can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He discreetly hands over to the accountant some cigars  scavenged from the party. From another pocket, he retriev and hands over some tins of food -- all valuable commodit From another pocket, perhaps not so valuable, but then wh knows, a gold lighter. Regarding this last item --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This, I don't know, maybe you can  trade it for something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler shrugs, It's the least I can do. The two stand  around a moment more before Schindler shrugs again, Sorry can't do more. He reaches out, pats Stern on the shoulder and, turning to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to go, I'll see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oskar --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler comes back, but, out of embarrassment or -- may he wants to get back to the party -- waits with some  impatience for Stern to tell whatever it is he wants to t him. Lowering his voice --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a guy. This thing happened.  Goeth came into the metalworks --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth moves through the crowded metalworks like a goodnat foreman, nodding to this worker, wishing that one a good  morning. He seems satisfied, even pleased, with the level production. Goldberg is with him. They reach a particular bench, a particular worker, and Goeth smiles pleasantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you making?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not daring to look up, all the worker sees of Goeth is th starched cuff of his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hinges, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rabbi-turned-metalworker gestures with his head to a  pile of hinges on the floor. Goeth nods. And in a tone mo like a friend than anything else --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got some workers coming in  tomorrow... Where the hell they from  again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yugoslavia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yugoslavia. I got to make room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shrugs apologetically and pulls out a pocket watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make me a hinge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Goeth times him, Rabbi Levartov works at making a hing as though his life depended on it -- which it does -- cut the pieces, wrenching them together, smoothing the edges, all the while keeping count on his head of the seconds ti away. He finishes and lets it fall onto the others on the floor Forty seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again the rabbi works feverishly -- cutting, crimping,  sanding, hearing the seconds ticking in his head -- and  finishing in thirty-five. Goeth nods, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very good. What I don't  understand, though, is -- you've  been working since what, about six  this morning? Yet such a small pile  of hinges?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He understands perfectly. So does Levartov; he has just  crafted his own death in exactly 75 seconds. Goeth stands him against the workshop wall and adjusts his shoulders. pulls out his pistol, puts it to the rabbi's head and pul the trigger... click.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumble) Christ --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annoyed, Goeth extracts the bullet-magazine, slaps it bac in and puts the barrel back to the man's head. He pulls t trigger again... and again there's a click.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slams the weapon across Levartov's face and the rabbi  slumps dazed to the floor. Looking up into Goeth's face, knows it's not over. As Goeth walks away --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tight on Schindler, a pensive nod, then a shrug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy can turn out a hinge in less  than a minute? Why the long story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rabbi Levartov, brought over to D.E.F., works at a table  with several others. As Schindler strolls by, the rabbi d to speak --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler has to think a moment before he can figure out the grateful man is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. You're welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dead chicken dangling from Hujar's hand, evidence of so kind. Goeth slowly pacing before a work detail of twenty so men standing still, silent, in a row.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody knows who stole the chicken.  A man walks around with a chicken,  nobody notices this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one confesses. Goeth nods, All right, takes a rifle fr a guard and shoots one of the workers at random. With thi added incentive, he waits for someone to tell him who sto the chicken. No one does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still nobody knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shrugs, Okay, points the rifle at another worker -- an boy of fourteen, shuddering and weeping, steps out of lin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth goes over to the boy, and, like a distant relative a small child, tries to get him to look at his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was you? You committed this crime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know who, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy nods, weeps, screams --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's pointing at the dead man. And Goeth astonishes the e assembly of workers and guards by believing the boy. He returns the rifle to the guard and walks away. Hujar s after him, then knowingly at the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A truck being loaded with supplies. Schindler signs for i and, appearing as rushed as he always does, returns the  clipboard to Stern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure, bring him over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler comes down the stairs with Klonowska. As they'r crossing through the factory --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distracted) That's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mechanic peering under the hood of Goeth's Adler. Leani in he accidentally knocks a wrench off the radiator into fan and there's an awful clatter before the engine dies. mechanic glances up horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As servants hoist a heavy, elaborately tooled saddle from Schindler's trunk - a gift for Goeth -- Schindler sees St coming toward him and glances skyward long-sufferingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mechanic, making adjustments to a metal press, glance up as Schindler moves past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the street stands a nervous young woman in a faded dress. She seems to be trying to summon the courage to cr over and onto the factory grounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just inside the factory, she waits as a guard telephones  Schindler's office. She can see the wall of windows from  where she's standing, and Schindler himself as he appears it, phone to his ear. He glances down at her disapproving and the guard hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman alone in a dismal room pulling on nylon stockin At a mirror, she applies make-up. She slips into a provoc dress. Puts on heels. A Parisian hat. And looks in the mi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler waits for her on the landing of the stairs. He  doesn't recognize her, but smiles to counter the unfortun possibility she's some old girlfriend he's forgotten. Rea him, she offers her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Krause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can tell now she doesn't know him. He seems relieved. leads her past Klonowska's desk and into his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He arranges a chair for her, goes to his liquor cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pernod? Cognac?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pours himself a drink, warms it in his hands, smiles,  clearly take with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grace with which she's carried herself up to this poi seems to evaporate as she struggles to find the words she wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say that no one dies here. They  say your factory is a haven. They  say you are good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler's face changes like a wall going up, a mask of  indifference like in the portrait of Adolf Hitler on the  wall behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who says that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler glances away from her. He seems weary suddenly, depressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Regina Perlman, not Elsa  Krause. I've been living in Cracow  on false papers since the ghetto  massacre. (pause) My parents are in Plaszow. They're  old. They're killing old people in  Plaszow now. They bury them up in  the forest. I have no money. I  borrowed these clothes. Will you  bring them here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler glances back at her, his face hard, cold, and  studies her for a long, long moment before --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't do that. You've been misled.  I ask one thing: whether or not a  worker has certain skills. That's  what I ask and that's what I care  about, get out of my office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares at him, frightened and bewildered. She feels t welling up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cry and I'll have you arrested, I  swear to God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hurries out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler barges into Stern's office. In a foul and aggre mood, he dispenses with pleasantries in order to admonish the accountant --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People die, it's a fact of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern has hardly had time to look up from the work on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to kill everybody? Great.  What am I supposed to do, bring  everybody over? Is that what you  think? Yeah, send them over to  Schindler, send them all. His place  is a "haven," didn't you know? It's  not a factory, it's not an enterprise  of any kind, it's a haven for people  with no skills whatsoever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern's look is all innocence, but Schindler knows better

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I don't know what you're  doing? You're so quiet all the time?  I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with concern) Are you losing money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not losing money, that's not  the point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What other point is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts; yells) It's dangerous. It's dangerous, to  me, personally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Schindler tries to settle down. Then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to understand, Goeth's under  enormous pressure. You have to think  of it in his situation. He's got  this whole place to run, he's  responsible for everything that goes  on here, all these people -- he's  got a lot of things to worry about.  And he's got the war. Which brings  out the worst in people. Never the  good, always the bad. Always the  bad. But in normal circumstances, he  wouldn't be like this. He'd be all  right. There'd be just the good  aspects of him. Which is a wonderful  crook. A guy who loves good food,  good wine, the ladies, making money...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And killing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll admit it's a weakness. I don't  think he enjoys it. (pause) All right, he does enjoy it, so what?  What do you expect me to do about  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing you can do. I'm not  asking you to do anything. You came  into my office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it isn't Stern who needs convincing; it's Schindler  himself. It's doubtful he even realizes this, but it's cl to Stern. Schindler sighs either at the predicament itsel or at the fact that he's allowed Stern to place him right the middle of it. He turns to leave, hesitates. He conduc a mental search for a name and eventually comes up with i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perlman, husband and wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He unstraps his watch, hands it to Stern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it to Goldberg, have him send  them over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Distant music, Brahms' lullaby, from the Rosner Brothers down by the women's barracks calming the inhabitants. Up  here on the balcony, Schindler and Goeth, the latter so d he can barely stand up, stare out over Goeth's dark kingd

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't fear us because we have  the power to kill, they fear us  because we have the power to kill  arbitrarily. A man commits a crime,  he should know better. We have him  killed, we feel pretty good about  it. Or we kill him ourselves and we  feel even better. That's not power,  though, that's justice. That's  different than power. Power is when  we have every justification to kill --  and we don't. That's power. That's  what the emperors had. A man stole  something, he's brought in before  the emperor, he throws himself down  on the floor, he begs for mercy, he  knows he's going to die... and the  emperor pardons him. This worthless  man. He lets him go. That's power.  That's power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems almost as though this temptation toward restrain this image Schindler has brush-stroked of the merciful  emperor, holds some appeal to Goeth. Perhaps, as he stare out over his camp, he imagines himself in the role, wonde what the power Schindler describes might feel like. Eventually, he glances over drunkenly, and almost smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amon the Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stable boy works to ready Goeth's horse before he arriv He sticks a bridle into its mouth, throws a riding blanke onto its back, drags out the saddle Schindler bought Goet Before he can finish, though, Goeth is there. The boy tri to hide his panic; he knows others have been shot for les

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir, I'm almost done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Goeth waits, patiently it seems, whistling to himself, the stable boy tries to mask his confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth gallops around his great domain holding himself hig in the saddle. But everywhere he looks, it seems, he's  confronted with stoop-shouldered sloth. He forces himself smile benevolently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth comes into his bedroom sweating from his ride. A wo with a pail and cloth appears in the bathroom doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to report, sir, I've been  unable to remove the stains from  your bathtub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth steps past him to take a look. The worker is almost shaking, he's so terrified of the violent reprisal he exp to receive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you using?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soap, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous) Soap? Not lye?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The worker hasn't a defense for himself. Goeth's hand dri down as if by instinct to the gun in his holster. He star at the worker. He so wants to shoot him he can hardly sta it, right here, right in the bathroom, put some more stai on the porcelain. He takes a deep breath to calm himself. Then gestures grandly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, go on, leave. I pardon  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The worker hurries out with his pail and cloth. Goeth jus stands there for several moments -- trying to feel the po of emperors he's supposed to be feeling. But he doesn't f it. All he feels is stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The worker hurries across the dying lawn outside the vill He dares a glance back, and at that moment, a hand with a gun appears out the bathroom window and fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sentries at their little table again, drinking Schind vodka. Nearby, Schindler and Stern outside Stern's barrac The accountant's tone is hushed:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he didn't steal so much, I could  hide it. If he's steal with some  discretion...

dialogues.speaker: STERN'S OFFICE, PLASZOW
dialogues.text: Goldberg delivers a stack of requisitions and invoices, a leaves without a word. Behind his desk, Stern takes a cur look at them and shakes his head in dismay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern comes in with the requisitions. Now it's Goldberg's turn to shake his head in dismay; he doesn't want to hear

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are fifteen thousand people  here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth says there's twenty-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are fifteen. He wants to say  sixteen, seventeen, all right, maybe  he can get away with it, but ten  thousand over? It's stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern, do me a favor, get out of  here. You want to argue about it, go  tell Goeth.

dialogues.speaker: LOADING DOCK, PLASZOW
dialogues.text: Stern watches truck being unloaded of bags of flour, rice and other supplies. Goeth nods to Hujar. Hujar calls a ha The workers climb down, close up the trucks. And, still h full, the trucks rumble off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SS auditors keep coming around,  looking over the books -- Goeth knows  this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trucks at the loading dock of Goeth's private warehou Polish workers, under Hujar's supervision, throwing down "surplus" bags of flour and rice -- the supplies for the  phantom 10,000 prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- you'd think he'd have the common  sense to see what's coming. No, he  steals with complete impunity.

dialogues.speaker: BARRACKS
dialogues.text: They can see Goeth's villa up on the hill; figures moving around behind the windows. There's another party going on there. Down here, as he nurses a drink from his flask,  Schindler thinks about what Stern has told him, and event shrugs, Fine, fuck him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you'll be rid of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Stern slowly shakes his head 'no.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Plaszow is closed, they'll have  to send us somewhere else. Where --  who knows? Gross-Rosen maybe. Maybe  Auschwitz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's the irony -- bad as it is, evil as Goeth is, it c get worse. Schindler understands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll talk to somebody. I'll  take care of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands over to Stern some negotiable items and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler and Senior SS Officers Toffel and Scherner shar table in same smoke-filled nightclub they met in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he done that's so bad -- take  money? That's a crime? Come on, what  are we here for, to fight a war?  We're here to make money, all of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's taking money and there's  taking money, you know that. He's  taking money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place produces nothing. I  shouldn't say that -- nothing it  produces reaches the Army. That's  not all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I'll talk to him about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a friend of yours, you want to  help him out. Tell me this, though --  has he ever once shown you his  appreciation? I've yet to see it.  Never a courtesy. Never a thank you  note. He forgets my wife at Christmas  time --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got no style, we all know that.  So, we should hang him for it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's stealing from you, Oskar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course he's stealing from me,  we're in business together. What is  this? I'm sitting here, suddenly  everybody's talking like this is  something bad. We take from each  other, we take from the Army,  everybody uses everybody, it works  out, everybody's happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler glances away to the floor show, nods to himself Glancing back again, he considers the SS men with great  sobriety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, in some eyes it doesn't  matter the amount we steal, it's  that we do it. Each of us sitting at  this table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His thinly veiled threat of exposure escapes neither SS m The air seems thicker suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't deserve your loyalty.  More important, he's not worth you  making threats against us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I threaten anybody here? I stated  a simple fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The threat still stands, despite Schindler's assurance  otherwise, and they all know it. So does Scherner's threa back to him, and they all know that, too. But Schindler j grins, and, glancing away --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, let's watch the girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In addition to the mid-day soup and break, there are bowl of fruit on the long work tables. At one of them, several workers are debating which of them will go upstairs to th Schindler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In honor of Schindler's birthday, Goeth has brought over  Stern and the Rosners -- the musicians, at the moment,  accompanying the best baritone in the Ukrainian garrison. Surrounded by his friends and lovers, Schindler cuts a ca He receives congratulations from the many SS men present the embraces, in turn, of Ingrid and Klonowska and Goeth. From Stern he gets a handshake. A Jewish girl from the shop floor is admitted and timidly approaches the drunken group around Schindler. The SS men consider her as a curiosity; Schindler, as he would any  beautiful girl. The music breaks and out of the silence c a small nervous voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...On behalf of the workers... sir...  I wish you a happy birthday...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hesitates. She's surrounded by SS uniforms and swasti and holstered guns. Schindler smiles; this is a beautiful girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her on the mouth. The smiles on the faces aroun them strain. Stern glances to heaven. Amon cocks his head like a confused dog. The kiss is broken, finally, and  Schindler smiles again with impunity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank them for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl backs away nodding anxiously; all she wants now out before someone -- her, Schindler, both of them -- get shot. Henry Rosner nudges Leo and they begin another song And the party tries to resume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were they not asleep in their barracks, the prisoners wou no doubt shudder at the sight: the clerks are setting up  their folding tables. Other figures move around the parade ground in the murky  dawn light: these raising a banner, those wheeling filing cabinets across the Appellplatz, this one wiring a phonog that one saturating a pad with ink from a bottle. Goldberg, Lord of Lists, moves from table to table handin out carbons of lists and sharing morning pleasantries wit the clerks. Some men in white appear like ghosts. A doctor's kid is  opened, a stethoscope removed. Another cleans the lenses his glasses. Someone sharpens a pencil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A trainman waving a lantern guides an engineer who's slow backing an empty cattle car along the tracks. It couples another empty slatted car with a harsh clank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The needle of the phonograph is set down on a pocked 78. first scratchy note of a Strauss waltz blare from the cam speakers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In his undershirt and shorts Goeth calmly smokes his firs cigarette of the morning as he listens to the music wafti up from down below. Down there on the Appellplatz, the entire population of t camp has been concentrated, some fifteen thousand prisone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though the music and banners struggle to evoke a country  fair, the presence of the doctors belie it. A sorting out process is going on here, the healthy from the unhealthy. A physician wipes at his brow with his handkerchief as se prisoners run back and forth, naked, before him. He makes his selections quickly: this one into this line, that one into that, and Goldberg moves them recording the names. Other groups of people run naked in front of other doctor and clerks. Notations are made and lines are formed. The beats down and the music lies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some still pulling their clothes back on, the first wave the "unfit" is marched onto the platform. A guard slides  open the gate of a cattle car and this first unlucky grou climbs aboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the camouflage of other women prisoners, Mila  Pfefferberg rubs a beet against her cheeks in desperate h of adding a little color to her skin. Amon Goeth, his shirtsleeves uncharacteristically rolled chats with one of the doctors as another group strips. Whether the topic is this Health Aktion or the unseasonab weather is unclear, but he nods approvingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commandant, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth glances up, finds Poldek among the group taking off their clothes. Pfefferberg appeals to him with a look tha asks, Do I really have to go through this, and Goeth turn to a clerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mechanic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pfefferberg is motioned away from the others; he's okay, doesn't have to be put through this indignity. He calls o to the Commandant again --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about my wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth thinks about it a moment before he nods, Yeah, okay sure. A clerk accompanies Pfefferberg and, making a notat on the way, finds Mila.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is higher, the cattle cars hotter. Prisoners' arm stretch out between the slats offering diamonds in exchan for a sip of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The needle of the phonograph is set down on another recor a children's song, "Mammi, kauf mir ein Pferdchen" (Mommy buy me a pony). Children are yanked from the arms of their parents. Waili protests quickly escalate to brawls with the guards. Revolvers and rifles aim at the sun and fire. Music, shot wails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guards traipse through a deserted barracks peering up at rafters, pulling planks from the floor, upending cots, lo for some children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small figure in red sprints across to another barracks, past it, to a crude wooden structure beyond it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An arm held out to either side, the small girl lowers her into a pit into which men have defecated. She works her w slowly down, trying to find knee and toeholds on the foul walls, ignoring the flies invading her ears, her nostrils Reaching the surface of the muck she lets her feet submer then her ankles, her shins, her knees, before finally touching harder ground. As she struggles to slow her  breathing, her racing heart, she hears a hallucinatory mu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is our place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sees eyes in the darkness; five other children are al there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waves of heat rise from the roofs of the long string of c cars. Inside, those who "failed" the medical exams bake a they wait for the last cars to be filled. Schindler's Mercedes pulls up. He climbs out and stares  transfixed. He notices Goeth then, standing with the othe industrialists, Bosch and Madritsch, and strolls over to  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to call you, I'm running a  little late, this is taking longer  than I thought. Have a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a shipment of Hungarians coming  in, I got to make room for them.  It's always something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances away at the train. The idling engine only part covers the desperate pleas for water coming from inside t slatted cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're complaining now? They don't  know what complaining is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grins. Schindler watches as another car is loaded. It' like they're climbing into an oven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you say we get your fire  brigade out here and hose down the  cars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth stares at him blankly, then with a What-will-you-th of-next? kind of look, then laughs uproariously and calls over to Hujar --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring the fire trucks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hujar heard him, he just doesn't get it. Finally he turns another guy and tells him to do it. STREAM OF WATER CASCADE onto the scalding rooftops. The f trucks are there, the hoses firing the cold water at the  cars on the people inside who are roaring their gratitude

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is really cruel, Oskar, you're  giving them hope. You shouldn't do  that, that's cruel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And amusing, not just to Goeth, but to the other SS offic standing around as well. Oskar moves away to talk with on of the firemen. At full extension, apparently the hoses s only reach halfway down the long line of cars. He returns Goeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got some 200-meter hoses back  at D.E.F., we can reach the cars  down at the end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth finds this especially sidesplitting, and hollers --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hujar!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE D.E.F. HOSES have arrived and are being coupled to  Plaszow's. As the water drenches the cars further back, t people inside loudly voice their thanks, and the guards a officers outside grin at the spectacle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does he think he's saving them  from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The joke takes on new dimension when, from the back of th D.E.F. trucks, boxes of food are unloaded. Accompanied by the laughter of the SS, Schindler moves along the string cars pushing sausages through the slats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth is almost hysterical. But slowly then, slowly, the  amusement on his face fades. His friend moving along the  cars bringing futile mercy to the doomed in front of coun SS men, laughing or not, is not just behaving recklessly  here, it's as though he were possessed. The water rains down on the last car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A German staff car pulls in across the factory gate, bloc it. Two Gestapo men climb out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl who brought Schindler best wishes on his birthda glances up from her work to the Gestapo crossing through factory. They climb the stairs to the upstairs offices an moments later, appear behind Schindler's wall of glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler leaning against his desk, drink in his hand, ca tries to assess his humorless arresters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not saying you'll regret it, but  you might. I want you to be aware of  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll risk it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler glances beyond them to a point outside his offi to Klonowska. She nods, she knows what to do, she'll make the phone calls, call in the favors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, sure, it's a nice day,  I'll go for a drive with you guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He snuffs out his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Settled comfortably in the backseat, Schindler glances id out the window. As the car makes a turn, though, he looks back. Apparently he expected it to turn the other way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys up front don't answer. Concern, for the first ti registers on Schindler's face. The car approaches a build block long with an ominous sameness to the windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler is made to empty his pockets, his money, cigare everything. Around him clerks speak in whispers, as if ra voices might set off head-splitting echoes along the narr monotonous corridors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's led down a flight of stairs into a claustrophobic tu He's taken past darkened cells. Past shadowy figures crou in corners and on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A water bucket. A waste bucket. No windows. This is not a cell for dignitaries; this arrest is different. Schindler, incongruous with the dank surroundings in his  double-breasted suit, slowly paces back and forth before cellmate, a soldier who looks like he's been here forever his greatcoat pulled up around his ears for warmth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I violated the Race and Resettlement  Act. Though I doubt they can point  out the actual provision to me. (pause) I kissed a Jewish girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler forces a smile. His cellmate just stares. Now  there's a crime; much more impressive, much more serious, than his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a stiff-backed chair sits a very unlikely defender of  racial improprieties -- Amon Goeth. To an impassive SS co behind a desk, Goeth tries to highlight extenuating  circumstances:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He likes women. He likes good-looking  women. He sees a good-looking woman,  he doesn't think. This guy has so  many women. They love him. He's  married, he's got all these women.  All right, she was Jewish, he  shouldn't have done it. But you didn't  see this girl. I saw this girl. This  girl was very good-looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth tries to read the guy behind the desk, but his face like a wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They cast a spell on you, you know,  the Jews. You work closely with them  like I do, you see this. They have  this power, it's like a virus. Some  of my men are infected with this  virus. They should be pitied, not  punished. They should receive  treatment, because this is as real  as typhus. I see this all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth shifts in his chair; he knows he's not getting anyw with this guy. He switches tacts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a matter of money? We can discuss  that. That'd be all right with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the silence that follows, Goeth realizes he has made a serious error in judgment. This man sitting soberly befor him is one of that rare breed -- the unbribable official.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're offering me a bribe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A "bribe?" No, no, please come on...  a gratuity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the man stands up and salutes, which thoroughly  confuses Goeth since Goeth is his inferior in rank. But h isn't saluting Goeth, he's saluting the officer who has j stepped into the room behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The colonel sits back down. Scherner pulls up a chair nex to Goeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Amon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scherner smiles and allows Goeth to shake his hand, but i clear, even to Goeth himself, that he has fallen from gra

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tall, thin, gray Waffen SS officer has a request for th Rosner brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to hear "Gloomy Sunday" again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's drunk, morose; it seems unlikely he'll be on his fee much longer. Indeed, as Henry and Leo Rosner begin the so an excessively melancholy tale in which a young man commi suicide for love -- the field officer staggers over to a  chair in the corner of the crowded room and slumps into i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We give you Jewish girls at five  marks a day, Oskar, you should kiss  us, not them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth laughs too loud, drawing a weary glance from Schern Schindler smiles good-naturedly. He's out, a little worse for wear perhaps, a little more subdued than usual. Takin him away from the others, taking him into his confidence

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God forbid you ever get a real taste  for Jewish skirt. There's no future  in it. No future. They don't have a  future. And that's not just good old- fashioned Jew-hating talk. It's policy  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THIN GRAY SS OFFICER is back in front of the musician swaying precariously, a drink in his hand --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Gloomy Sunday" again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again they play the song. Again he staggers across the cr room to his chair in the corner, paying no attention to t visiting Commandant from Treblinka or anybody else --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- We can process at Treblinka, if  everything is working? I don't know,  maybe two thousand units a day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shrugs like it's nothing, or with modesty, it's unclea Goeth is dully impressed; Schindler, only politely so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Auschwitz. Now you're talking.  What I got is nothing, it's like  a... a machine. Auschwitz, though,  now there's a death factory. There,  they know how to do it. There, they  know what they're doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AGAIN THE GRAY OFFICER wavering before Henry and Leo. Thi time they don't wait for him to ask for it --

dialogues.speaker: LEO ROSNER
dialogues.text: "Gloomy Sunday" As the man stumbles back to his chair, th Rosners not only play the song again, they play with it, him, this one somber man in the corner staring at them al gratefully, wrenching from the song all the sentimentalit they can, as if they could actually drive him to kill him No one else in the room is aware of the exchange going on between them -- this man and this music -- which the brot play as if it were an invocation. Eventually, though, som does become aware, if not of the intention, at least of t repetition, and interrupts the spell --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough -- Jesus -- God --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music falls apart. The brothers find Goeth in the cro looking at them like, Come on, for Christ's sake play  something else. Which they do -- defeated -- some innocuo Von Suppe. Goeth turns back to one of his guests. Glancing back, as they play, to the corner, the Rosners s the gloomy SS officer getting slowly up from his chair. H stands there for a moment, staring at nothing, then slowl makes his way out onto the balcony where he stands in the night air, absolutely still, in silhouette to the Rosners And, ruining a perfectly good party, he takes out a gun a shoots himself in the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a distance, Schindler can be seen arguing with an SS officer who's trying to hand him papers, orders of some k which the irate industrialist refuses to accept. Here, closer, carrying blankets and bundles, Schindler's  workers are marched under heavy guard out of the factory its annexes and across the fortified yard. His people are being taken. Where, is unclear. Schindler  abruptly breaks off the discussion with the SS man, climb into his car and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A creek flowing gently through marshy ground under an umb of trees. Leo John and his five year old son, on their kn catching tadpoles, seem unaware of, or at least not distr by, a ghastly endeavor going on beyond them: Bodies being exhumed out of the earth, out of the mass gr in the forest. The dead lay everywhere, victims of the gh massacre, victims of Plaszow. Arriving, Schindler sees Goeth standing up at the tree li Approaching him, furious, he hesitates. He sees a wheelba trundled by Pfefferberg, a corpse in it. He fears the bod is Mila's, but then sees her trundling another barrow, an corpse in it. Goeth calls to Schindler --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you believe this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth shakes his head, dismayed. Schindler joins him and  stares at a pyre of bodies built by masked and gagging  workers, layer upon layer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to live my life, they  come up with this? I got to find  every body buried up here? And burn  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's always something. He glances off. The pyre has reach the height of a man's shoulder. The workers move around i dousing it with gasoline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You took my workers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indignant) They're taking mine. When I said  they didn't have a future I didn't  mean tomorrow. (pause) Auschwitz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sighs at the unfairness of it all, the dissolution of kingdom. His glance finds his man, Leo John, over at the  stream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is good. I'm out of business  and he's catching tadpoles with his  son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tight on the gleeful boy with a tadpole in his hand. Behi him, smoke from the pyre rises into the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler, in silhouette against the wall of glass, stare down at his deserted factory, his silent machines, the da empty spaces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light pouring in through the windows. White sheets over t furniture like shrouds over the dead. Schindler's persona things are gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler's Mercedes, the backseat piled high with suitca A border guard returns his passport to him. The barrier i lifted and he crosses into Czech countryside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A church in the main square of a sleepy hamlet. A priest his parishioners, including Emilie Schindler, emerging fr it, morning Mass over. Some guys outside a bar/cafГ©, hanging gout, drinking, no the elegantly dressed gentleman outside the town's only h They recognize him. They come over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, how you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler, the clothes, the car, the suitcases, the great difference between their respective stations in life. Somehow their old ne'er-do-well friend has managed to do  quite well, and it amazes them. Across the square, Emilie has noticed him; and he, her. B neither makes a move toward the other. Finally she walks  away; which Schindler interprets correctly to mean, Yes,  check into the hotel. He tips the porter extravagantly an turns back to the guys from the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me buy you a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except for the clothes of the working class clientele, th scene is reminiscent of the SS nightclub in Cracow: Schindler, the great entertainer, working his way around tables making sure everybody's got enough to drink, makin sure everybody's happy. A guy at a table with a girl gest him over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oskar - my friend Lena.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do? (to them both) What can I get you, what're you  drinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing's changed. Then again,  something has changed, hasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things worked out. I made some money  over there, had some laughs, you  know. It was good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you're back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I'm back, and you know what I'm  going to do now? I'm going to have a  good time. So are you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gestures to the bartender to refill his friend's and h date's drinks, pats the guy on the shoulder and wanders o to the next table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy has to think; not because he doesn't know, but be his old friend Oskar is so many things it's hard to know  which description to use. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a salesman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman asleep in the bed. The girl from the bar. In his  robe, at the window, Schindler calmly smokes as he stares out at the NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The town, off in the distance, nestled against the mounta The sun, just coming up. Closer, here, ramshackle structu a long abandoned factory of some kind. Schindler, in leather riding gear, climbs down off a Moto Guzzi motorcycle. He slowly wanders around, peers in thro broken windows, wanders around some more. Tight on his face, torn between conflicting choices, or  realizing there's no choice, or only one choice, and hati it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler and Goeth on the balcony of the villa, drinking

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want these people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These people, my people, I want my  people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth considers his friend, greatly puzzled. Below them l the camp, still operating, at least for now, until the  shipments can be arranged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you, Moses? What is this?  Where's the money in this? What's  the scam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, this is "good business" in your  opinion. You've got to move them,  the equipment, everything to  Czechoslovakia -- it doesn't make  any sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not telling me something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good for me -- I know them, I'm  familiar with them. It's good for  you -- you'll be compensated. It's  good for the Army. You know what I'm  going to make?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Artillery shells. Tank shells. They  need that. Everybody's happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth finds this whole line of reasoning impossible to  believe. He's sure Schindler's got something else going o here he's not telling him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're probably scamming me somehow.  If I'm making a hundred, you got to  be making three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler admits it with a shrug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you admit to making three, then  it's four, actually. But how?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did, but you didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth studies him, searching for the real answer in his f He can't find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, all right, don't tell me, I'll  go along with it, it's just irritating  to me I can't figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you have to do is tell me what  it's worth to you. What's a person  worth to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth thinks about it in the silence. Then a slow nod to  himself. He's going to make some money out of this even i he can't figure it out. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's one worth to you? That's the  question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE KEYS OF A TYPEWRITER slapping a name onto a list -- 1 184 LEVARTOV -- the letters the size of buildings, the so as loud as gunshots -- TIGHT ON THE FACE OF A MAN -- Rabbi Levartov -- the hinge maker Goeth tried to kill with a faulty revolver -- THE KEYS HAMMER another name -- PERLMAN -- TIGHT ON TWO ELDERLY FACES -- a man, a woman -- the paren of "Elsa Krause." IN HIS SMALL CLUTTERED PLASZOW OFFICE - Stern transcribes D.E.F.workers' names from a Reich Labor Office document to the list in his typewriter, Schindler' List.

dialogues.speaker: NAME
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON SCHINDLER slowly pacing the six or seven steps  Stern's cramped office allows, nursing a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poldek Pfefferberg... Mila  Pfefferberg...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE KEYS typing В‘PFEFFE- PFEFFERBERG'S face, tight. MILA face, tight. CURRENCY, hard Reichmarks, in a small valise. As Goeth lo at it, he mumbles to himself --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A virus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING DOWN THE LIST of names, forty, fifty. The sound of the keys. Stern pulls the sheet out of the machine, rolls another, types a name. EQUIPMENT BEING LOADED onto trucks outside Madritsch's Pl factory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can do the same thing I'm doing.  There's nothing stopping you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madritsch is shaking his head В‘no' to Schindler's appeal make his own list, to get his workers out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done enough for the Jews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE KEYS typing another name -- A FACE, a man, A FACE, a  woman, A FACE, a child -- COGNAC SPILLING into a glass. The glass coming up to  Schindler's mouth, hesitating there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The investors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A NAME -- A FACE -- one of the original D.E.F. investors. ANOTHER NAME -- ANOTHER FACE -- another of the Jewish  investors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of them. Szerwitz, his family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STERN GLANCES UP with a look that asks Schindler if he's  sure about this one. He is. The keys type SZERWITZ -- TIGHT ON THE FACE of the investor who stole from Schindle the one he threatened to have killed by the SS, and the f of his sons -- THREE OR FOUR PAGES of names next to the typewriter. Ster trying to count them, estimates --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four hundred, four fifty --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE TRUNK OF SCHINDLER'S MERCEDES yawning open. He takes small valise from it and heads for Goeth's villa. THE KEYS typing ROSNER -- TIGHT ON Henry Rosner, the violinist. TIGHT ON his brothe Leo, the accordionist. SCHINDLER AND BOSCH, the other Plaszow industrialist. The same appeal Schindler made to Madritsch; the same answer, В‘no.' MOVING DOWN another page of names.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About six hundred --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE SOUND OF THE KEYS OVER the face of a boy, the "chicke thief." Over THE FACE OF A GIRL, the one who hid in the p of excrement. Over the FACES we've never seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight hundred, give or take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) Give or take what, Stern -- how many --  count them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STERN RUNS HIS FINGER down the pages of names, trying to  count them more precisely. BLACKJACK, dealt by GOETH. They're betting diamonds, he a Schindler. A queen falls and Goeth groans his misfortune. THE FACE OF Goeth's maid. GOETH SWEEPS his hold card against the table, is thrown a four, sweeps it again and gets a jack. A NAME we don't recognize is typed. A FACE we don't recognize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler leafing through the page of names, counting the drinking, to the sound of the typewriter. Eventually, qui to himself --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern heard him and stops typing, glances over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can finish that page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern resumes where he left off, but then hesitates again There's something he doesn't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did Goeth say? You just told  him how many you needed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't sound right. And Schindler doesn't answer. He' avoided telling Stern the details of the deal struck with Goeth, and balks telling him now. Finally awkwardly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm buying them. I'm paying him. I  give him money, he gives me the  people. (pause) If you were still working for me I'd  expect you to talk me out of it,  it's costing me a fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern had no idea. And has no idea now what to say. Schindler shrugs like it's no big deal, but Stern knows i is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give him the list, he'll sign it,  he'll get the people ready. I have  to go back to Brinnlitz, to take  care of things on that end, I'll see  you there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern is really overcome by what this man is doing. What can't figure out is why. Silence. And then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finish the page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern turns back, does as he's told. Schindler drinks. Nothing but the sound of the typewriter keys. And then no at all. The page is done. The rest will die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler in front of a large assembly, party pin in his  lapel, as usual, imposing SS guards on either side of him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks out over his audience, the citizens of Brinnlitz local government officials, many of them appearing bewild by him or the "situation" that has arisen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was born here, my wife was born  here, my mother is buried here, this  is my home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His estranged wife is there. So are the guys he was drink with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really think I'd bring a  thousand Jewish criminals into my  home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone seems to breathe sighs of relief as if they've b waiting for him to say this, to dispel the disturbing rum they've heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are skilled munitions workers --  they are essential to the war effort --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The noise begins, his audience's angry reaction. Raising  pitch of his own voice --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- It is my duty to supervise them --  and it is your duty to allow me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He barely gets it all out before the protests drown him o The uproar reaches such a clamoring level there's no poin in his continuing.

dialogues.speaker: GOETH'S VILLA
dialogues.text: Goeth, at his writing desk, endures the bureaucratic tedi of signing memoranda, transport orders, requisitions. He  comes to Schindler's list, initials each page and signs t last with no more interest than the others. He hands the  whole stack of paperwork to Marcel Goldberg, Personnel Cl Executor of Lists, Gangster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goldberg has the signature page of the list in a typewrit He carefully aligns it and types his own name in a space  allowed by the bottom margin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a folding table in the middle of the field, Schindler  signs his name to Reich Main Office directives, Evacuatio Board and Department of Economy form, Armaments contracts Around him, the new camp is taking shape: Electric fences are going up, watchtowers, barracks; shipments of heavy  equipment, huge Hilo machines, are being off-loaded from  flatbed train cars; SS engineers stand around frowning at the lay of the land, some drainage problem no doubt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A train full of people destined for Auschwitz pulls away  from the platform. As Goldberg gathers his paperwork, a  prisoner approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I on the list?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What list is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows what the prisoner means and the prisoner knows h knows. He means Schindler's List.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The good list? Well, that depends,  doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prisoner knows that, too, and discreetly turns over t Goldberg a couple of diamonds from the lining of his coat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Names on a notepad, the first few crossed out. Goldberg t the next name onto a page of The List, squeezing it into upper margin, and crosses that one out on the pad. He rolls the page down, types another name, tires of the  exacting task, tears the handwritten page of names from t notepad, crumples it and throws it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler, on his way back to his hotel after a night of  drinking, is jumped by three guys, wrestled to the ground and brutally kicked. As the forms of his attackers move away, he catches a gli of one of them -- his "friend" who admired his car when h first arrived back in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pfefferberg, his head under the hood of a German staff ca adjusting the carburetor. Goldberg comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Poldek, how's it going? (Pfefferberg ignores  him) You know about the list? You're on  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I'm on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to stay on it? What do you  got for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pfefferberg glances up from his work and studies the  blackmailing collaborator for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I got for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Takes diamonds to stay on this list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pfefferberg suddenly attacks him with the wrench in his h beating him across the shoulders and head with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll kill you, that's what I got for  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goldberg goes down, tries to scramble away on his knees, blows coming down hard on his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, all right, all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes it outside the garage and runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cattle car is coupled to another, the pin dropped into  place. On the platform, clerks at folding tables shuffle  paper while others mill around with clipboards, calling o names. Thousands of prisoners on the platform, some climbing ont strings of slatted cars on opposing tracks. Some already them, most standing in lines, changing lines, the end of virtually indistinguishable from the beginning of another Paperwork. Lists of names. Pens in hands checking them of Some bound for Brinnlitz, the rest for Auschwitz, if they can be properly sorted from one another. A boy is allowed to remain in a line with his father; his mother is taken to another line composed of women and gir This segregation is the only recognizable process going o the others, if they exist, are apparent only to the clerk and guards, and maybe not even to them. It is chaos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A train snakes across the dark landscape.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Stern, wedged into a corner of an impossibly crowded car. This train may be headed for Schindler's hometown, but it no more comfortable than the others on their way to Ausch Birkenau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train idles at a crossing in the middle of nowhere. Moving across the faces peering out from between the slat it becomes apparent there are only male prisoners aboard. Below, on a dirt road, a lone Polish boy stands watching. Just before an empty train roars past from the other dire obscuring him, his hand comes up and across his neck maki the gesture of a throat being slit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train pulls into the small quiet Brinnlitz station. T doors are opened and the prisoners begin climbing down. A the far end of the platform, flanked by several SS guards stands Schindler. To his customary elegant attire he has  added a careless accouterment, a Tyrolean hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leading a procession of nine hundred male Jewish "crimina through the center of town, Schindler ignores the angry t and denouncements and the occasional rock hurled by the g citizens of Brinnlitz lining the streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the towering Hilo machines, a meal of soup and brea awaits the workers. As they're sitting down to it, Schind addresses them --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be interested to know I  received a cable this morning from  the Personnel Office, Plaszow. The  women have left. They should be  arriving here sometime tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees Stern among the workers, smiles almost impercepti turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A train backs slowly along the tracks toward an arched  gatehouse. The women inside the cattle cars don't need a  sign to tell them where they are, they've seen this place nightmares. Pillars of dark smoke rise from the stacks in the sky. It's Auschwitz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stunned women climb down from the railcars onto an im concourse bisecting the already infamous camp. As they're marched across the muddy yard by guards carrying truncheo Mila Pfefferberg stares at the place. It' so big, like a  city, only one in which the inhabitants reside strictly  temporarily. To Mila, under her breath --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are the clerks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So often terrified by the sight of a clerk with a clipboa it is the absence of clerks which unsettles the woman now as though there remains no further reason to record their names. Mila's eyes return to the constant smoke rising beyond th birch trees at the settlement's western end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler comes out of his office and, passing Stern's de mumbles --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're in Auschwitz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Stern can react, Schindler is out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he strides across the factory courtyard toward his  motorcycle, Schindler is intercepted by some Gestapo men have just emerged from their car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your friend Amon Goeth has been  arrested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) I'm sorry to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are some things that are  unclear. We need to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love to, it'll have to wait until  I get back. I have to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The looks on their faces tell him he's not going anywhere

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, okay, let's talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Breslau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breslau? I can't go to Breslau. Not  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These guys are serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young silver-haired doctor moves slowly along rows of  Schindler's women, considering each with a pleasant smile even as he makes his selections, with tiny gestures, for death chambers. He pauses in front of one.
