dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old are you, Mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She could lie, and he'd have killed her for it. She could tell the truth, and he'd have her killed for that, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Sir, a mistake's been made. We're  not supposed to be here, we work for  Oskar Schindler. We're Schindler  Jews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor nods pensively, understandingly, it seems. The

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who on earth is Oskar Schindler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances around hopelessly. One of the SS guards who  accompanied the women from Plaszow speaks up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had a factory in Cracow.  Enamelware.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor nods again as if the information were valuable as if it meant something to him. It doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A potmaker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles to himself and gets on with the "examination,"  this woman to this line, this other one to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a dank cell, in uniform, Amon Goeth waits. Schindler i on his way, hopefully. Maybe he's already here. Schindler will vouch for him. Schindler will straighten this out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a large room, Schindler sits before a panel of twelve  sober Bureau V investigators and a judge of the SS court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything you say will be held in  confidence. You are not under  investigation. You are not under  investigation. Mr. Goeth is. He is  being held on charges of embezzlement  and racketeering. You're here at his  request to corroborate his denials.  Our information onto his financial  speculations comes from many sources.  On his behalf there is only you. We  know you are close friends. We know  this is hard for you. But we must  ask you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stole our country blind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Schindler's absence, the workers attempt to operate th unfamiliar machines, to figure out the unfamiliar process manufacturing artillery shells. There's movement, there's noise, the machines are running, but little is being prod Untersturmfuhrer Jose Liepold, the Commandant of Schindle new subcamp, moves through the factory conducting an impr inspection. He points out to a guard a kid no more nine,  sorting casings at a work table, and another boy, ten or  eleven, carrying a box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mila and another woman cross back toward their barracks  carrying a large heavy pot of broth. Not more than a hund meters away stand the birch trees and crematoria, the smo pluming even now, at NIGHT out of the darkness appear  "apparitions," skeletal figures which surround the two wo or rather the soup pot between them, dipping little metal cups into it, over and over. Too startled to speak, Mila can only stare. The apparitio clamor around the pot a moment more, than furtively slip  back into the same darkness from which they came. Mila an the other woman exchange a glance. The pot is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Schindler now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In his en, over cognac, Auschwitz Commandant Rudolf Hoss  considers the documents Schindler has brought: the list, travel papers, the Evacuation Board authorization. Hoss n at them, then at Schindler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right, a clerical error has  bee made. (pause) Let me offer you this in apology for  the inconvenience. I have a shipment  coming in tomorrow, I'll cut you  three hundred from it. New ones.  These are fresh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler seems to think about the offer as he nurses his drink. It's "tempting."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train comes, we turn it around,  it's yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate it. I want these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ones on the list in Hoss' hand. Silence. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't get stuck on names.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, because you get to know them? Because you begin to s them as human beings? Schindler suddenly has the awful fe that the women are already dead. Hoss misinterprets the l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, it creates a lot of  paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large assembly of women. Guards calling out names from list. As each woman steps out of line, a guard unceremoni brushes a swathe of red paint across her clothes. New col are formed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler, standing at the end of the platform stone-face watches the women whose names he is "stuck on," whose clo are slashed with red paint, climbing onto the cattle cars As the cars fill, a train on another track arrives. The  "fresh" ones Schindler turned down. As the gates are clos on the women's cars, the gates of the others are opened a the people spill out. A horrified cry suddenly breaks through the noise of the  engines. One of Schindler's women, locked in, has seen he son among those coming down off the train on the opposing track. Another cry erupts, and another, another, as the women sp their children, confiscated from the Brinnlitz factory,  brought here. Schindler becomes aware of what's happening and, passing  over other children, tries to corral these particular boy many of whom have noticed their mothers now and are echoi their tortured cries with their own. Schindler manages to gather them together, the fifteen or twenty boys, and, in the middle of the crowded platform,  appears to a guard:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are mine. They're on the list.  These are my workers. They should be  on the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points across to the women's train, then down to the b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're skilled munition workers.  They're essential.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guard glances from the frantic gentleman to the anxio brook around him. These are essential workers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler is nodding his head, trying to think. The women are shrieking their sons' names. The guard, who heard it  all, every excuse imaginable, is just turning away when  Schindler thrusts his smallest finger at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their fingers. They polish the insides  of shell casings. How else do you  expect me to polish the inside of a  45 millimeter shell casing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guard stares at him dumbly. This he hasn't heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a mirage in the distance they appear -- the women, t children, guards, Schindler, marching across a field towa the factory. At the perimeter of the camp, at the wire, the men watch approaching procession. It appears to them that the women are covered in blood -- or -- could it be paint? They're  walking, they're fine, some are even smiling. Liepold isn't smiling. Neither is Schindler; at least not the outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The machines are silent, the people are not. Women are in their husbands' arms, sons in their fathers'. There's foo on the tables but it's largely ignored, the reunion takin precedence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler stands before the assembled camp guards. They a seated at the long tables, their food getting cold, waiti for him to say whatever it is he has to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under Department W provisions, it is  unlawful to kill a worker without  just cause. Under the Businesses  Compensation Fund I am entitled to  file damage claims for such deaths.  If you shoot without thinking, you  go to prison and I get paid, that's  how it works. So there will be no  summary executions here. There will  be no interference of any kind with  production. In hopes of ensuring  that, guards will no longer be allowed  on the factory floor without my  authorization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes meet Liepold's, hold his icy stare, then return the guards, most of whom look like tired middle-aged  reservists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For your cooperation, you have my  gratitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he steps away he gestures to some kitchen workers. The tear open cases of schnapps and begin setting the bottles out on the tables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler strolls through his factory looking over the  shoulders of the workers, nodding his approval. The place in full operation, finally; the people, having figured ou the complicated Hilos, turning out shells by the caseload Schindler pauses at one of the machines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. It's taken a while to calibrate  the machines, but it's going good  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler nods. Then frowns. He leans down and taps at th crystal of one of the gauges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't right, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The worker kneels down, takes a look. It looks right to h Reaching over, Schindler changes the calibration of the  machine with a cavalier adjustment to a knob -- and all t gauge readings shift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There. That looks right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wanders off. The worker stares after him. He's just sc up settings that took weeks to get right. Schindler comes up to another worker, Levartov, the  hingemaker. He's at a machine buffing shells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it going, Rabbi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler nods, watches him work, eventually glances away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sun's going down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levartov, following Schindler's gaze, nods uncertainly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is Friday, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should be preparing for the  Sabbath, shouldn't you? What are you  doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levartov just stares. It's been years since he's been all indeed inclined, to perform Sabbath rites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got some wine in my office. Why  don't we go over there, I'll give it  to you. Come on, let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler heads off. The rabbi keeps staring. Schindler  gestures back to him, offering casually --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levartov looks around. Finally, he hangs up his goggles a follows after Schindler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the shadow of a watchtower, among the roof-high tie of bunks strung with laundry, Levartov recites Kiddush ov a cup of wine to workers gathered around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On their bunks, the guards relax with schnapps, cards and magazines. One of them becomes distracted by a distant so Some of the others begin to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conversations cease. The barracks gradually becomes quiet silent, all the guards straining to hear. It sounds like. singing. It sounds like Yiddish singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a watchtower, a night sentry, unsure where it's coming from, listens to the distant singing. It seems like it's  emanating from the surrounding hills, from the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At his small desk, Liepold is typing a letter, denouncing Schindler most likely. The pounding keys bury all other s but when he pauses to reread what he's typed, he hears it the singing, faint, far away. He goes to his window, peer out, listens for a moment more, then hears nothing. Only the night creatures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to an apartment opens from the inside revealing  Emilie Schindler. She coolly considers the visitor on her doorstep, her estranged husband, looking great as usual,  bottle of wine in his hand, smiling as if nothing is wron between them, as if nothing is wrong in the entire world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two of them at the kitchen table in a modest apartmen drinking, at least he is. He's trying to ask her somethin but he's not sure how to put it, he wants to get it right Finally the words just tumble out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to come work for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, he's said it. But the bewildered look on Emilie's  face wonders, That's what was hard for you to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to live with me, I  wouldn't ask that. (pause) It's a nice place. You'd like it. It  looks awful. You get used to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's the only woman he's even known who could make him  nervous just sitting across a table from him, saying noth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right -- (now he'll be honest) We can spend time together that way.  We can see each other, see how it  goes -- without the strain of --  whatever you want to call it when a  man, a husband and a wife go out to  dinner, go have a drink, go to a  party, you know. This way we'll see  each other at work, there we are,  same place, we see how it goes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His voice trails off. A shrug adds, What do you think? Sh doesn't answer, but she does love him. He loves her, too. It really is a shame they're not right for each other and never will be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern glances up from his work; Schindler and Emilie have come in and are walking toward the accountant's desk. He  gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Itzhak Stern, Emilie Schindler. My  wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the doormen and waiters of Cracow, Stern too never  imagined Schindler was married and has trouble hiding his astonishment now. He extends his hand to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern is my accountant and friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sounds strange to Stern hearing Schindler actually say it. He's never said it before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emilie's offered to work in the  clinic. To... work there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not sure what she's going to do there, she's not a n or a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to her) That's very generous of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler nods, looks around, shrugs, offers his arm to h wife, perhaps to take her on a tour of the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a pleasure meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleasure meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Schindlers leave. Stern sits back down at his desk an smiles. He's never seen Schindler so uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler comes in carrying a radio. He sets it down on a bench where Pfefferberg's working on the frame of a machi motor with a blow torch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you fix it? The radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How should I know? It's broken. See  what you can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves. Pfefferberg plugs it into an outlet and switch it on. It works perfectly. A waltz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a male barracks, a group of workers including Pfefferb huddle in a corner around the radio, straining to hear th heavy static a broadcast by the BBC, the Voice of London, sketchy report of an Eastern offensive by Allied Russian  forces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a camp doctor attends to sufferers of dysentery, Schin and Emilie sort pairs of prescription glasses from a parc shipped from Cracow. Stern comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler sifts through the glasses still in the box, com up with a particular pair and holds them proudly. Not qui sure what he's seeing is real --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They arrived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They arrived, can you believe it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern allows himself a smile, a rare thing for him. Schindler carefully slips the new glasses onto the  accountant's face. He looks around the clinic, Stern,  eventually settling on Emilie, crystal clear, standing ne a picture on the wall which, in other circumstances, he'd find less than reassuring: Jesus, his heart exposed and i flames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a quiet corner of the clinic, Schindler concentrates o the disquieting news Stern has brought him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've received a complaint from the  Armaments Board. A very angry  complaint. The artillery shells, the  tank shells, rocket casings --  apparently all of them -- have failed  quality-control tests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler nods soberly. Then dismisses the problem with a shrug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's to be expected. They  have to understand. These are start- up problems. This isn't pots and  pans, this is a precise business.  I'll write them a letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're withholding payment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sure. So would I. So would  you. I wouldn't worry about it. We'll  get it right one of these days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Stern is worried about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a rumor you've been going  around miscalibrating the machines. (Schindler doesn't  deny it) I don't think that's a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern slowly shakes his head 'no.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They could close us down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler eventually nods, in agreement it seems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Call around, find out  where we can buy shells and buy them.  We'll pass them off as ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern's not sure he sees the logic. Whether the shells ar manufactured here or elsewhere, they'll still eventually  reach their intended destination, into the hearts and hea of Germany's enemies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you're saying, but I  don't see the difference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't? I do. I see a difference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll lose money. That's one  difference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fewer shells will be made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's another difference. The main one. The only one  Schindler cares about. Silence. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern, if this factory ever produces  a shell that can actually be fired...  I'll be very unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nineteen year old boy with his hands in the air stands  terrified before Commandant Liepold and the revolver he  wields. Workers, trying to reduce the likelihood of getti hit by a stray bullet when Liepold fires on the boy -- wh seems a certainty -- scramble out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liepold swings the gun around at the voice, pointing it f a moment at Schindler, who is striding toward him, then a the barrel back at the boy's head, and yells --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Department W does not forbid my  presence on the factory floor. That  is a lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waves a document at Schindler, throws it at him. Schindler doesn't bother picking it up. Instead, pointing the boy, he yells to Liepold --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot him. Shoot him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liepold is so startled by the command, he doesn't shoot. doesn't lower the gun, though, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot him without a hearing. Come  on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His finger is on the trigger, Liepold is torn, frustrated hating the situation he has created. As the moments witho a blast stretch out, both and Schindler begin to settle d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sabotaged the machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler glances to the boy. Then at the silent Hilo bes him. Part of it is blackened from an electrical fire. To boy, concerned --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The machine's broken?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy, too terrified to speak, nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prisoner is under the jurisdiction  of Section D. I'll preside over the  hearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liepold glances to him. He seems almost distraught by the destruction of the machine, Schindler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The machine is under the authorization  of the Armaments Inspectorate. I  will preside over the hearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liepold isn't sure that's correct, but he has no  documentation, at least not on him, to refute it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the machine-tool section, a "judicial table" has been up. At it sit Schindler, Liepold, two other SS officers, an attractive German girl, a stenographer. The "saboteur, the boy, Janek, stands before the court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm unfamiliar with the Hilo machines.  I don't know why I was assigned there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commandant Liepold was watching me trying to figure it ou I switched it on and it blew up. I didn't do anything. Al did was turn it on. Gone tonight is Schindler's usual shop-floor familiarity. studies the boy solemn-faced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're not skilled at armaments  work, you shouldn't be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a lathe operator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler dismisses the defensive comment with a wave of hand and gets up. He comes around and paces slowly before the boy. Eventually, Janek dares to speak again --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler glances up at him distractedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did adjust the pressure controls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler stops, looks to the panel, and back to the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that much about them. Somebody  had set the pressure controls wrong.  I had to adjust --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler slams the back of his hand so hard across Janek face, the boy almost falls. He's stunned. So are the othe at the table. They've never seen such violence from the  Direktor. He roars --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stupidity of these people. I  wish they were capable of sabotaging  a machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler's hand comes up again and Janek recoils, expect another blow. Schindler manages to hold it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him out of my sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A guard escorts the prisoner away. The panel members glan among themselves. Is that it? Schindler faces them and gr in dismay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liepold at his desk, typing again. This time there is no  doubt he is composing a letter denouncing Schindler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler and Emilie, her arm in his, stand around like  unwanted guests at the party. They probably are. Him anyw The other guests include local politicians who fought and failed to keep his camp out of Brinnlitz. Whenever his glance meets one of theirs, they smile tight

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Emilie) Isn't this nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not at all nice. He feels out of place, a feeling he not accustomed to. Fortunately, a man in uniform, someone Schindler can relate to, approaches cheerfully, his hand  outstretched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oskar, good of you to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding, I never miss a party.  Police Chief Rasch, my wife Emilie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a lovely home. It is nice.  Big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man lives well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God, you don't have a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Emilie) Wine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods. Schindler goes off in search of the bartender. Rasch watches after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your husband's a very generous man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wry) He's always been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rasch and Schindler sharing cognac in the privacy of the  Police Chief's study. Beyond the closed doors, the party  continues, the sounds filtering in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rasch calmly nurses his drink, his eyes revealing nothing what's going on behind them, except that the statement  requires some elaboration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of these days the Russians are  going to show up unannounced at my  gate. I'd like the chance to defend  myself. I'd like my wife to have  that chance. My civilian engineers.  My secretary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause; then,  philosophically) We're losing the war, aren't we.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It kind of looks that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blithely) Pistols?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pistols, rifles, carbines ... (long pause) I'd be grateful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rasch smiles faintly. Yes, he's familiar, as are official throughout much of Europe, with the gratitude of Oskar  Schindler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poldek Pfefferberg holds up a pistol, feels its weight, p it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) Careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pfefferberg smiles, lowers the gun, kneels beside an open crate of weapons: a couple of revolvers and rifles, an ol carbine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From high above the factory, Stern can be seen among the  machines talking with a worker. The man points up and ret to his work. Stern stares up, puzzled. He locates a ladder that connec the shop-floor to a series of overhead planks and, with  trepidation, climbs. He reaches a shaky landing high above the machines, navig the primitive catwalks with great care, comes to a large  water tank near the workshop ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Above the rim of the tank, amid rising steam, Schindler's head appears. Then disappears. Stern climbs a set of rung on the tank, reaches the top and finds inside, lolling in the steaming water, Schindler and the blonde stenographer from the trial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither Schindler nor the blonde seems the least bit  embarrassed. Only Stern. He tries hard to pretend the gir isn't there, but he just can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll talk to you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, what, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler floats over closer to him, waits for him to rep whatever it is he has come to report, leans closer. Final quietly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any money I don't know  about? Hidden away someplace?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler thinks long and hard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence except for the gently lapping water. Half-joking

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, am I broke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern glances away, doesn't answer, just stares off. And slight, slight smile, a gambler's philosophical smile upo being purged of his wealth, appears on Schindler's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the distance, a lone boxcar, stark against the winter  landscape. There are patches of snow on the ground. A col wind blows through bare trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poldek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tight on Poldek Pfefferberg's eyes behind a welder's mask He turns from his work to the voice, welding torch in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The torch firing at ice as hard as metal, blue flame, whi steam. Pfefferberg's eyes behind the mask again,  concentrating. Around the abandoned boxcar, in the gruesome cold, stand  Schindler, Emilie, a doctor, some workers and some SS gua watching, waiting. Pfefferberg steps back. Sledge hammers pound at locks. Hands pull at levers. The doors begin to slide. Out of darkness, from inside the boxcar as the doors slid open, Schindler's face is revealed, tight. He stares for interminable moment before walking slowly away. Inside the boxcar is a tangle of limbs, a pyramid of corp frozen white. From a distance, a tableau: the boxcar, the workers and g and Emilie outside it, Schindler, off to himself several  steps away, all of them still as statues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beyond a country church, among the stone markers of a sma cemetery, walk Schindler and a priest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been suggested I cremate them  in my furnaces. As a Catholic I will  not. As a human being I will not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The priest nods; he seems relatively empathic. He offers alternative --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an area beyond the church  reserved for the burial of suicides.  Maybe I can convince the parish  council to allow them to be buried  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These aren't suicides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The priest knows that. But he also knows that the provisi of Canon Law regarding who can and cannot be buried in  consecrated ground are narrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are victims of a great murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a corner of the factory, workers hammer at pine lumber They are building coffins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As workers harness horses to carts, others hoist the coff into them. Schindler is there, watching. He glances up at one of the guard towers, expecting, perhaps, to be felled a bullet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beyond the wire, Rabbi Levartov leads the horse-drawn car Around him walk a minyan -- a quorum of ten males necessa for the rite. A few guards lag behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Work continues, but it's apparent in their eyes they are  only physically here; in spirit they are all walking alon the carts, one great moral force. The roar of a machine suddenly, inexplicably, dies. Then  another. And another. Schindler, standing at the main pow panel, pulls the last of the switches, and the factory pl into absolute silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just beyond the perimeter of the Catholic cemetery, the m quickly and quietly recites Kaddish over the dead as thei coffins are lowered into individual graves. Then, there is only a low breathing of wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amon Goeth, in civilian clothes, emerges from a car. His  eyes, sallow from inadequate sleep, sweep across the fort compound with envy. It's a nice place Oskar's got here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern, at a window, stares down at Goeth beside his car.  Softly, gravely --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler appears beside Stern, glances down. He's lost  weight, Goeth. The old suit he wears seems too big for hi Alone down there he seems disoriented.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably looking for a handout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Workers glance up at a horrible apparition from the pit o their foulest dreams -- Amon Goeth crossing through the  factory. Schindler, his arm around the killer's shoulder as if he  were a long lost brother, leads him across the shop-floor proudly pointing out to him the huge thundering Hilo mach

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler takes an old suitcase from his office closet, s it on his desk, snaps it open revealing clothes, Goeth's  uniforms, his medals. The ex-Oberstrumfuhrer touches the  fabric gently, then glances up gratefully to his friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beyond the frosted glass of Schindler's office door, Ster can see the wavering forms of the two Nazi Party members  sharing cognac and stories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warmed by cognac and friendship, Goeth comes through the  factory again carrying the suitcase, Schindler at his sid steering him to some degree. Goeth's hand comes up to his cheek as if to brush away a  bothersome fly. But it isn't a fly. One of the workers ha spit on him. He turns in disbelief. Silence as his hand drops to his side, to the holster he  forgets isn't there. He glances around for SS guards... w aren't there. He looks to Schindler, thoroughly confused, and whispers --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are the guards?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guards aren't allowed on the  factory floor. They make my workers  nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goeth stares at him bewildered. Then again at the worker spit. Then at other workers, the resolve in their eyes. They know he has no power here, and sense he has no power anywhere. His own eyes drift to a woman with yarn in her  lap, knitting needles in her hands. Is this a dream?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll discipline him later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler good-naturedly throws an arm around Goeth's sho and leads him away. The workers watch as the two Germans  disappear out the factory doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A guard slowly turns the dial of a radio, finding and los in static several different voices in several languages,  none of them lasting more than a moment. Depression hangs over the barracks. Most of the guards ar straining to hear the news they've been fearing for some  time now, some on their bunks just staring, one at a wind peering out at the black face of a forest as if expecting at any moment, to see Russian or American troops appear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another radio. Workers, like the guards, straining to hea The dial finds, faint, mired in static, the idiosyncratic voice of Winston Churchill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler on Liepold's doorstep. The two men considering  each other across the threshold. Radio static filters out from Liepold's room. The word "Eisenhower" cuts through b the speaker's voice is buried again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time the guards came into the  factory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All twelve hundred workers and all the guards are gathere for the first time on the factory floor. Tension and  uncertainty surround them. It's ominously quiet. Then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The unconditional surrender of Germany  has just been announced. At midnight  tonight the war is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not his intention to elicit celebration. Indeed, hi words, echoing and fading in the factory, echo the doubts they all feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, you'll begin the process  of looking for survivors of your  families. In many cases you won't  find them. After six long years of  murder, victims are being mourned  throughout the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not by Untersturmfuhrer Liepold. He stands with his men,  dying to lift his rifle and fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've survived. Some of you have  come up to me and thanked me. Thank  yourselves. Thank your fearless Stern,  and others among you, who, worrying  about you, have faced death every  moment. (glancing away) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's looking at the guards, thanking them, which thorough confuses the workers. Just when they thought they knew wh his sentiments lay, he's thanking guards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've shown extraordinary discipline.  You've behaved humanely here. You  should be proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or is he attempting to adjust reality, to destroy the SS combatants, to alter the self-image of both the guards an the prisoners? Moving across the SS men's faces, they rem inscrutable. Schindler turns his attention back to the  workers, and, not at all like a confession, but rather li simple statements of fact:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a member of the Nazi party. I'm  a munitions manufacturer. I'm a  profiteer of slave labor, I'm a  criminal. At midnight, you will be  free and I will be hunted. (pause) I'll remain with you until five  minutes after midnight After which  time, and I hope you'll forgive me,  I have to flee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That worries the workers. Whenever he leaves, something  terrible always seems to happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In memory of the countless victims  among your people, I ask us to observe  three minutes of silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the quiet, in the silence, drifting slowly across the  faces of the workers -- the elderly, the lame, teenagers, wives beside husbands, children beside their parents, fam together -- it becomes clear, if it wasn't before, that b as a prison and a manufacturing enterprise, the Brinnlitz camp has been one long sustained confidence game. Schindler has never stood still so long in his life. He d now, though, framed by his giant Hilo machines, silent at the close of the noisiest of wars, his head bowed, mourni the many dead. When he finally does look up he sees that he is the last do so. The faces, few of which he recognizes, are all loo at him. He turns to speak to the guards along the wall ag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you've received orders from  our Commandant -- which he has  received from his superiors -- to  dispose of the population of this  camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apprehension spreads across the factory like a wave. Pfefferberg tightens his grip on the pistol under his coa His ragtag irregulars do the same, the rest of their ersa "arsenal" concealed behind a machine. To the guards:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now would be the time to do it.  They're all here. This is your  opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guards hold their weapons, as they have from the mome they arrived here tonight, at attention, waiting it seems to be given the official order from their Commander, Liep who appears ready to give it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or... (he shrugs) ...you could leave. And return to  your families as men instead of  murderers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long, long silence. Finally, one of the guards slowly low his rifle, breaks ranks and walks away. Then another. And another. And another. Another. When the last is gone, the workers consider Liepold. He  appears more an oddity than a threat. He is more an oddit than a threat. And he knows it. He turns and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A watchtower. Abandoned. The perimeter wire. No sentries. The guard barracks. Deserted. The SS is long gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler and Emilie emerge from his quarters, each carry a small suitcase. In the dark, some distance away from hi Mercedes, stand all twelve hundred workers. As Schindler his wife cross the courtyard to the car, Stern and Levart approach. The rabbi hands him some papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've written a letter trying to  explain things. In case you're  captured. Every worker has signed  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler sees a list of signatures beginning below the  typewritten text and continuing for several pages. He poc it, this new list of names.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern steps forward and places a ring in Schindler's hand It's a gold band, like a wedding ring. Schindler notices inscription inside it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Hebrew. It says, 'Whoever saves  one life, saves the world.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler slips the ring onto a finger, admires it a mome nods his thanks, then seems to withdraw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) I could've got more out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern isn't sure he heard right. Schindler steps away fro him, from his wife, from the car, from the workers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) I could've got more... if I'd just...  I don't know, if I'd just... I  could've got more...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oskar, there are twelve hundred people  who are alive because of you. Look  at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'd made more money... I threw  away so much money, you have no idea.  If I'd just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There will be generations because of  what you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't do enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schindler starts to lose it, the tears coming. Stern, too The look on Schindler's face as his eyes sweep across the faces of the workers is one of apology, begging them to  forgive him for not doing more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This car. Goeth would've bought this  car. Why did I keep the car? Ten  people, right there, ten more I  could've got. (looking around) This pin --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rips the elaborate Hakenkreus, the swastika, from his  lapel and holds it out to Stern pathetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two people. This is gold. Two more  people. He would've given me two for  it. At least one. He would've given  me one. One more. One more person. A  person, Stern. For this. One more. I  could've gotten one more person I  didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He completely breaks down, weeping convulsively, the emot he's been holding in for years spilling out, the guilt  consuming him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They killed so many people... (Stern, weeping too,  embraces him) They killed so many people...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From above, from a watchtower, Stern can be seen down bel trying to comfort Schindler. Eventually, they separate, a Schindler and Emilie climb into the Mercedes. It slowly p out through the gates of the camp. And drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A panzer emerges from the treeline well beyond the wire o the camp and just sits there growling like a beast. Sudde it fires a shell at nothing in particular, at the night - an exhibition of random spite -- then turns around and ro back into the forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a watchtower, a couple of workers, having witnessed tank's display of impotent might, can make little sense o it. Below, many of the workers mill around the yard, wait to be liberated. No one seems to know what else to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some Czech partisans emerge from the forest. They come do the hill and casually approach the camp. Reaching the wir they're met by Pfefferberg and some other workers, rifles slung over their shoulders. Through the fence --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) So what are you doing? You're free  to go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the Russians arrive. Until then  we're staying here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The partisan shrugs, Suit yourself, and wanders back towa the trees with his friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five headlights appear out of the night, five motorcycles marked with the SS Death's-head insignia. They turn onto road leading to the camp gate and park, the riders shutti off the engines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shapes materialize out of the darkness within the camp. Several armed and dangerous Jews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the cyclists fill their tanks with gasoline borrowed f the camp, the workers keep their rifles pointed at them. NCO in charge lines the gas cans neatly back up against t wire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He climbs onto his motorcycle. The others climb onto thei And drive away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lone Russian officer on horseback, tattered coat, rope reins, emerges from the forest. As he draws nearer, it be apparent to the workers assembling on the camp yard, that the horse is a mere pony, the Russian's feet in stirrups  nearly touching the ground beneath the animal's skinny  abdomen. He reaches the camp, climbs easily down from the horse an in a loud voice, addresses the hundreds of workers standi at the fence:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have been liberated by the Soviet  Army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it? This one man? The workers wait for him to say more. He waits for them to move, to leave, to go home. Fi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few of the workers come out from behind the fence to ta with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been in Poland?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just came from Poland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are there any Jews left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Russian has to think. Eventually he shrugs, 'no,' not that he saw, and climbs back onto his pony to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where should we go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Don't go east, that's  for sure, they hate you there. (pause) I wouldn't go west either if I were  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shrugs and gives his little horse a kick in the ribs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could use some food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Russian looks confused, glances off. The quiet hamlet Brinnlitz sits there against the mountains not half a mil away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that a town over there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it is. But the idea that they could simply walk over there is completely foreign to them. The Russian rid away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All twelve hundred of them, a great moving crowd coming  forward, crosses the land laying between the camp, behind them, and the town, in front of them. Tight on the FACE of one of the MEN. Tight on TYPEWRITER KEYS rapping his NAME. Tight on A PEN scratching out the words, "METAL POLISHER" a form. Tight on the KEYS typing, "TEACHER." Tight on his FACE in the crowd. Tight on the face of a woman in the moving crowd. The key typing her name. The pen scratching out "LATHE OPERATOR." The keys typing "PHYSICIAN." Tight on her face. Tight on a man's face. His name. Pen scratching out  "ELECTRICIAN." Keys typing "MUSICIAN." His face. A woman's face. Name. Pen scratching out "MACHINIST." Key typing "MERCHANT." Face. "CARPENTER." Face. "SECRETARY." Face. "DRAFTSMAN." Face. "PAINTER." Face. "JOURNALIST." Face. "NURSE." Face. "JUDGE." Face. Face. Face. Face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A street of apartment buildings in a working class  neighborhood of the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to a modest apartment opens revealing Oskar  Schindler. The elegant clothes are gone but the familiar  smile remains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, how you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Poldek Pfefferberg out in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things are great, things are great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things don't look so great. Schindler isn't penniless, bu he's not far from it, living alone in the one room behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm having a drink, come on in, we'll  have a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean where have you been? Nobody's  seen you around for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) I've been here. I guess I haven't  been out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought maybe you'd like to come  over, have some dinner, some of the  people are coming over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Yeah, that'd be nice, let me  get my coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pfefferberg waits out in the hall as Schindler disappears inside for a minute. The legend below appears:

dialogues.speaker: HE WAS HANGED IN CRACOW FOR CRIMES AGAINST HUMANITY.
dialogues.text: Schindler reappears wearing a coat, steps out into the ha forgets something, turns around and goes back in.

dialogues.speaker: STILL.
dialogues.text: He comes back out with a nice bottle of wine in his hand, and, as he and Pfefferberg disappear down the stairs toge

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mila's good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids are good? Let's stop at a store  on the way so I can buy them  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't need anything. They just  want to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. I'd like to pick up  something for them. It'll only take  a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their voices face. Against the empty hallway appears a fa trace of the image of the factory workers, through the wi walking away from the Brinnlitz camp. And the legend:
